Bost                  The Bost Bulletin Friend,  As we celebrate Presidents' Day tomorrow, it's important to note the impact each president has had on our nation's history, including Illinois' own Abraham Lincoln. His dedication to freedom is a shining example of the values our country represents. Here's what I've been up to this week.   Protecting Our Children in Schools Having the Securing Our Schools Act, a bill I introduced, signed into law by the President is one of my proudest achievements while serving in Congress. This law created the School Violence Prevention Program (SVPP) to provide law enforcement with the appropriate tools and technology they need to make classrooms safer. Starting this week, the SVPP is accepting applications through April 8, 2020 for this year’s round of grant funding. For more information, please visit here. As a former first responder, I encourage local government leaders, school administrators, and law enforcement to apply ASAP!  Safeguarding Veteran Votes Ensuring Americans have a say in who leads our government is a right our veterans overseas fight for every day. Too often, however, our men and women serving across the world are unable to have their absentee ballots arrive to the States on time for the collection deadline.This is completely unacceptable, which is why I am proud to tell you that I have cosponsored the Counting All Military Votes Act to improve voting accessibility for American active duty service members. Our military men and women overseas are committed to keeping American diplomats and citizens safe and deserve peace of mind knowing that their ballot will be counted in a timely manner.     Empowering the Postal Service Since its creation in 1775, the USPS has remained one of the most reliable government agencies. In fact, it is one of the few explicitly mentioned in the United States Constitution. Today, the USPS employs over 600,000 workers and continues to be an integral function of our government and economy. However, due to a mandate passed over a decade ago, the USPS is obligated to pre-fund its future pensions, losing the agency millions of dollars every year. I'm proud to tell you that legislation I cosponsored, the USPS Fairness Act, passed the House last week. This bill will make sure that employees within the USPS will receive the same retiree health funding benefits that apply to all other federal agencies and allow the USPS to invest in itself for the first time in years.  Prior to its passage, I spoke on the House Floor in support of this legislation. To hear my remarks, please click the link below.     Sending Valentines for Veterans On Thursday, I joined my colleagues in writing Valentine's Day messages to be sent to veterans living in the Washington, D.C. area. Veterans selflessly signed up to defend the freedoms of our great country without asking for anything in return. As a Marine and father of a Marine, I was honored to take part in this small gesture of appreciation for those who have served our nation.    Protecting Correctional Officers Our district is home to United States Penitentiary Marion, but like many facilities, it is not staffed at the proper level. Studies show that understaffed facilities have more assaults against workers and more inmate suicides. Recently, I led a letter asking the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to provide the Bureau of Prisons with direct-hiring authority, which would allow individual facilities to hire the staff they need on their own timelines. This week, I was honored to accept the Legislative Appreciation Award from the Council of Prison Locals for my work on this issue and will continue to make sure the safety of correctional facility staff and inmates is a top priority.      Investing in Illinois Waterways I met with Illinois members of the Waterways Council to discuss the funding and maintenance of our system of inland waterways and ports. With millions of tons of cargo transported on the Mississippi River every year, this issue is one of my top priorities. As a member of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I will continue to make sure Southern Illinois's waterways are taken care of.     Meeting with Southern Illinois Community Colleges Earlier in the week, I had the chance to meet with Interim President Dr. Kathleen Curphy and Don Patton with Shawnee Community College as well as several administrators and trustees from John A. Logan Community College to discuss access to grants, lowering costs of tuition, and bolstering job training for career and technical education (CTE) programs. As a member of the Congressional CTE Caucus, I will continue to support these critically important programs.   It was a productive week here in Washington, with a schedule jam-packed full of meeting with folks from across our district. I’m looking forward being back in Southern Illinois for our district work week.  I hope you enjoy Presidents' Day tomorrow and are able to relax and reflect on the blessings in your life. Enjoy your week!  -Mike                  Unsubscribe

name: Congresswoman Carol Miller
subject: Protecting the Right to Life
body: Congressman Carol Miller ?      Dear Friend, Happy Presidents' Day weekend! On this day we honor all that our Presidents have done to lead our nation into the prosperous and powerful one it is today. This week was filled with many exciting developments. I introduced legislation to fill the remaining gaps in the Federal Employee Paid Leave Act, that ensures all federal employees are guaranteed 12 weeks paid family leave after the birth, fostering, or adoption of a child. It is important we provide working families with resources to care for their young children, in order to achieve a fulfilling work-life balance in our modern economy.? Additionally, I offered an amendment in the Oversight and Reform Committee while discussing DC Statehood. The amendment would ensure all children born alive after an abortion attempt are granted the full right to life just as any other child would have. The Constitution guarantees the right to life for all citizens and we must do everything we can to stand up for our most innocent and smallest ones. Unfortunately, this amendment failed along party lines. Watch my full testimony by clicking the picture below.  ? The House also voted on the Equal Rights Amendment this week. Ispoke  in opposition of this legislation because it would create the basis for taxpayer funded abortion at the federal level, would force healthcare providers to perform abortions, and would permanently allow abortions up until the moment of birth for any reason. This attack on life is tragic.? As always, do not hesitate to reach out to any of my offices in Washington, Huntington, Beckley, and Bluefield. I am here to help you and greatly value your input. Sincerely, Carol Miller Member of Congress Issue of the Week: Encouraging Our Girls to Join STEM Wednesday was Girl Day on the Hill! I joined with DiscoverE and Collins Aerospace to encourage young girls to explore a STEM career. Did you know that 50% of the workforce is women, but only 28% of the STEM workforce is women? We need to change that. If we provide an environment that gives girls the confidence and assurance they need to choose a STEM career, we can close this gender gap within our next generation. ? In my remarks, I urged us all to remember President Lincoln's insightful words, "A house divided against itself, cannot stand." I look forward to continuing to work together in unity with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to benefit all Americans.  Continue reading for a brief update on my work on your behalf last week.  Advocating for our Heroes  It was a pleasure to meet with Dr. Miguel LaPuz, VA VISN 8 Director. We discussed issues impacting local Veterans, and current plans to expand the Zephyrhills Clinic and North Pinellas VA clinics. I appreciate his commitment to ensure Veterans receive the care they deserve and look forward to continuing to work with him on critical improvements to the system.   In last week’s VA Economic Opportunity Subcommittee Hearing we discussed a variety of draft bills to help improve educational opportunities for Veterans. This included my legislation to modernize GI Bill certificate of eligibility processing, as well as bills I support that would improve the STEM education and VET-TECH programs. Click here to listen to my remarks during the hearing. Additionally, I was glad to see this bill I supported signed into law last week. It will help Veterans develop the skills and educational acumen to attain lucrative jobs in STEM industries. Protecting Patients  Last week, I was proud to become the newest member of the Congressional ALS Caucus. ALS a debilitating and horrific disease that claims the life of many Americans far too soon. Additionally, a disproportionate number of Veterans have been diagnosed with ALS, which is alarming. I have long been a supporter of legislation and federal funding designed to increase research that will lead to better treatments and cures for rare diseases, like ALS. However, as an active member of the ALS Caucus, I will be able to do even more. I join this caucus in honor of Doug, who is a constituent, a Veteran and a friend of mine. Doug has bravely battled ALS for almost 15 years. I am inspired by Doug’s courage, his family’s commitment and by his best friend, Gary, who has become a fierce and vocal advocate for all ALS patients who struggle with this disease. Together, I am optimistic that our Caucus can be a catalyst for change and that we will do what it takes to find a cure.   It was great to meet with local leaders from Advent Health Hospitals last week. They were in town to discuss how we can improve transparency in healthcare costs and protect patients from surprise medical bills.  Surprise medical billing typically occurs when a patient receives an unexpected bill after a medical procedure due to items that were not covered by his/her insurance.  As I promised the leaders from Advent Health, I will continue to work on fixing this problem.   Additionally, in last week’s Health Subcommittee hearing, I appreciated the chance to share stories from women in my district who feel strongly about the need to protect the sanctity of life. Click here to listen to me share their words.  Learning from You  I had the distinct pleasure of meeting with Florida athletes from this year’s Special Olympics and listen to their inspirational stories. This wonderful program promotes inclusion, celebrates diversity and encourages us all to reach our highest potential.   I also had the opportunity to meet with visually impaired and blind constituents who are members of the National Federation for the Blind. We discussed accommodations and assistive technologies that can be utilized to ensure those with disabilities are fully able to participate in society. As someone with significant visual impairments myself, I am grateful for their work and continued advocacy. I will continue to support their efforts.   One of my favorite parts of the job is having the opportunity to meet with young people and listen to their ideas about how to improve our nation. Last week, I was fortunate to meet with students from Sunlake High School in Land O' Lakes. They were in D.C. as part of the Junior State of America program. I found them to be bright, insightful and optimistic about the future.   I was honored to meet with a constituent from Palm Harbor, Mr. Joe Hedger, who owns a local small business. We discussed the need to invest in sustainable infrastructure projects throughout the nation, and the need for national standards on composites and other new manufacturing technology.   Additionally, I will be hosting a teletown hall this Wednesday, February 19, 2020 at 6:00 p.m. This forum allows a maximum number of constituents to participate. On average, several thousand constituents join in each teletown hall for the entire hour-long exchange. This is just one of the multiple ways that I communicate with my constituents on a regular basis. I look forward to the opportunity to provide a brief update of what I have been working on in Washington and answering your questions. The system will be randomly dialing constituents; however, if you want to ensure your participation you can call in directly at 1-888-480-3641.  Ensuring Public Safety  In last week’s Consumer Protection and Commerce Subcommittee we discussed proposed legislation to encourage innovation and safety in the regulation of autonomous vehicles. We want to benefit from the major advances this technology will offer while ensuring that the public is protected. I am grateful that legislation I authored is currently being negotiated into the bipartisan package. My bill would ensure that seniors and those with disabilities are considered when developing regulations for this new technology. Strengthening Strategic Alliances  Andy Athens and Maynard Wishner led efforts by Greek- American and American-Jewish communities to strengthen ties between Greece and Israel. Each year an Athens-Wishner award is given to an individual for showing leadership on Eastern Mediterranean issues and for bolstering the relationship between the Jewish and Hellenic diasporas. I was proud to receive this prestigious honor last week.   Constituent Corner  Last week, I received the following email from a constituent.  “Congressman Bilirakis has a caring and efficient staff who are concerned about and serve their constituents. I greatly appreciate all that you have done to help me with the Department of Veteran’s Affairs. It took only a few days (instead of up to 6 weeks) for the VA to acknowledge my Medicare. Thank you for supporting disabled service connected veterans and their spouses.”  This is just one example of the work we do each and every day. Constituent services are a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you!  Community Connection  While I'm away in Washington, I have a team of am fortunate to have a team of staff that attends events, meets with constituents and helps me stay abreast of what is happening in our community. Here are just a few samples of events they attended in our community last week.  My team was happy to join the Dade City Chamber of Commerce and help celebrate the ribbon cutting for ACE Hardware Store.   My team enjoyed the unveiling of 40 new exhibits at the West Pasco Historical Society, Dr. Rao Musunuru Library. It is wonderful to see a celebration of our community's rich cultural heritage and a desire to preserve the past.   During last week's Greater Pasco Chamber of Commerce meeting, my team enjoyed learning about the importance of preventative eye care and screenings from Dr. Grace Levy-Clarke from the University of South Florida.  My team enjoyed meeting with U.S. Department of Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia during his visit to Tampa last week. He discussed the strength of our economy and plans to increase apprenticeship programs throughout the nation.      Thank you for reading this week’s update. Feel free to share this e-newsletter with friends and encourage them to sign up! Remember, you can always stay in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.  Sincerely,Gus Bilirakis                      Washington D.C. If you have friends or family members who would like to subscribe to these updates, please share with them the following LINK. STANDING FOR LIFE   Every life is a precious gift from God, and it's my privilege - and my responsibility - to defend all human life. This week, I was honored to receive the "True Blue" Award from Family Research Council Action in recognition of my strong pro-life record. In Congress, I will continue fighting to protect the most vulnerable among us.      ***  WORKING FOR PA-13  This week, it was a pleasure to meet with Pastor Gary Dull from Faith Baptist Church in Altoona and Pastor Nathan Kistler from the Hope to the Hill International Ministries. Pastor Dull brought the good news of Jesus Christ to bipartisan members of Congress, and he discussed the importance of presenting Christ lovingly and directly to all the people in America.      ***  Combatting the drug crisis requires an “all-hands-on-deck” approach, and I am grateful to President Trump and the Appalachian Regional Commission for investing critical resources in Somerset County. A new $1 million grant will allow Twin Lakes Center to expand its capacity to care for those in recovery and to continue offering hope and support to our community. Read more in the Somerset Daily American.    ***  Earlier this week, I had a great meeting with athletes and advocates from the PA Special Olympics. These young Pennsylvanians are incredible members of our community, and it’s a privilege to support their work in PA-13.    ***  Tim McMahon, President of Triangle Tech, visited Washington with great news of the opening of the 6th Triangle Tech Campus in Chambersburg. Education and training earned at Triangle Tech can lead to jobs that provide family-sustaining wages throughout PA-13 - an important resource for our community.     ***  Thanks to Pennsylvania members of the American Library Association for taking the time to meet with me with this week. We had a productive conversation about the importance of local libraries in PA-13 and beyond!     ***  On Wednesday, I met with John Fiorill, 2nd Vice President of the Fraternal Order of Police Pennsylvania State Lodge, from Mechanicsburg. Our law enforcement officers put their lives on the line to protect our community, and it is critical for Congress to support them.     ***  It was great to meet with members of the American Composites Manufacturing Association, including Dustin Troutman from Creative Pultrusions, Inc. in Bedford County. We had a productive conversation about infrastructure updates and job growth in PA-13.     ***  ONE MORE THING   From higher wages to lower unemployment and more jobs, the economy is working for American families. Our pro-growth, pro-worker agenda is delivering results, and we need to keep moving in the right direction.    *** Thank you for taking the time to learn about what I was working on this week, and I look forward to updating you again next Sunday. REMINDER: Additional updates can be found on my FACEBOOK PAGE. name: Senator Lamar Alexander
subject: Latest from Lamar: Reviewing budget recommendations from the president
body: Latest from Lamar, Notes from the Senate Desk *Important news from this past week:* - I wrote an op-ed with Senator Richard Burr of North Carolina on the Coronavirus that originated in Wuhan, China, now called COVID-19. As chairman of the Senate health committee, I will continue to monitor this outbreak, and I believe the actions of our public health officials, state and local partners, and the Trump administration are helping to prevent the spread of the virus in the United States. Read more here [link 1]. - President Trump announced this week his intent to nominate [link 2] Tyreece Miller to serve as the United States Marshal for the Western District of Tennessee. Deputy Chief Miller knows how to get results and how to get local, state and federal agencies to work together. - The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers announced [link 3] that construction of Chickamauga Lock in Chattanooga will receive its sixth straight year of funding, which will help keep up to 150,000 trucks off I-75 and keep the cost of shipping goods low for manufacturers across the state. - This week I voted to approve the Iran War Powers Resolution. This vote is about the United States Constitution. It preserves the commander in chief's Article II constitutional responsibility to defend the country and Congress' Article I responsibility to declare war. *Reviewing the president's budget recommendations* This week, President Trump announced [link 4] his budget recommendations for fiscal year 2021. I appreciate the president's budget suggestions and will carefully consider them as Congress begins the process of funding the federal government for the next fiscal year. Under the Constitution, it is Congress' job to set spending priorities and pass appropriations bills, and my priorities will continue to be making sure our national defense, national laboratories, the National Institutes of Health and national parks have the resources they need. In his budget, the president called for ending the practice of surprise medical billing. Ending surprise medical billing is a problem almost everyone wants fixed, and is a perfect example of how Congress and the president can work together to reduce out of pocket health care costs for patients. The president tweeted [link 5] about the necessity of fixing this problem earlier this week: [image = [link 6] I am also glad to see the budget continues to include the president's proposal to rebuild our national parks. The Restore Our Parks Act [link 7], legislation that I introduced with Senators Portman, Warner, and King, is based on the president's proposal and will cut in half the maintenance backlog at our national parks. This legislation is the only way to address the deferred maintenance backlog in our 419 national parks, and the Trump Administration agrees. This is especially important for Tennessee, given that the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is the most visited national park in the country. The budget proposes a major increase in funding for career and technical education programs to help train more workers for our growing economy. The budget also proposes new education tax credit scholarships to give low-income families more of the same choices that wealthier families already have when choosing a school for their children. [image = I enjoyed meeting with the Tennessee Fraternal Order of Police this week. I appreciate everything they do to keep our communities safe. *Chickamauga Lock construction will continue for sixth consecutive year* Under the work plan released this week by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Chickamauga Lock will receive $101.7 million to continue construction for the sixth consecutive year. This funding will keep construction of the new Chickamauga Lock on time and schedule. This is great news for East Tennessee since it will help keep up to 150,000 trucks off I-75 and keep the cost of shipping goods low for manufacturers across the state. More U.S. senators ask to increase funding for the Army Corps of Engineers than any other part of the budget, and I worked hard to provide record funding for the Corps to ensure we could keep federal lock and dam projects on track. The work plan also provides $8.1 million for the J. Percy Priest project, which includes an additional $2.2 million for maintenance of recreation features and greenway trail improvements. The work plan also includes $2.163 million for dredging at Memphis Harbor McKellar Lake, which is good news for West Tennesseans. *Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:* *Fox News: Op-Ed by Sen. Alexander & Sen. Burr: Coronavirus prevention steps the U.S. government is taking to protect you* [link 8] *Tennessean: Op-Ed by Brian Reisinger: How Sen. Lamar Alexander had his 'Howard Baker moment' during the Trump impeachment trial* [link 9] *Chattanooga Times Free Press: Chickamauga Lock gets more funding this year, but Trump budget plan could end replacement work next year* [link 10] Listen to the Farm Bureau. *#240 in Lamar Alexander's Little Plaid Book* ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] [link 9] [link 10] Contact Information: Website: Office Location: Washington, DC Office 455 Dirksen Office Building, Washington, DC 20510 Phone: (202) 224-4944 | Fax: (202) 228-3398 Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

During the first half of February, I attended President Donald Trump's inspiring State of the Union address, traveled with President Trump for the Opportunity Now Summit, and met with school leaders on education issues. I also had the opportunity to personally award the winner of the Congressional App Challenge. Below you can also find information on this year's Congressional Art Competition.  State of the Union Address In President Donald Trump's State of the Union address, he reaffirmed his commitment to keeping his promises.  South Carolina has seen his kept promises first-hand. At 2.3 percent, South Carolina’s unemployment rate is at a record low. Since President Trump’s election, 122,000 jobs have been created in South Carolina—including 19,000 manufacturing jobs, wages increased 4 percent by an average of $5,000 for families in South Carolina. Read my full statement on the President's State of the Union address here.   Opportunity NOW Summit  I was grateful to travel with President Trump for the launch of Opportunity NOW, a new nationwide campaign to revitalize under-served cities and towns across America.    Opportunity NOW Summit   Meetings with Midlands Technical College and Magnet Schools of America This week I met with the Midlands Technical College Board of Trustees to talk about the importance of technical colleges which teach the skills necessary to succeed in our dynamic workforce.   Meeting with Midlands Technical College  Last week, I was recognized by the Magnet Schools of America (MSA) as a Champion of Magnet School Excellence and to be a steadfast supporter of magnet schools, in South Carolina and nationally.    Meeting with the Magnet Schools of America     Congressional App Challenge Winner Congratulations to Milan Dutta of Lexington for winning the Congressional App Challenge for South Carolina’s Second District with his app, “BioHelper.” The Congressional App Challenge is open to all middle and high school students in South Carolina’s Second District. Every year, the winner from the Second District is featured online and the winning app will be eligible to be displayed in the United States Capitol. Details on the 2020 competition will be announced in October.    Awarding the Congressional App Challenge Winner, Milan Dutta of Lexington    Congressional Art Competition Each year, my colleagues and I in the House of Representatives participate in a nationwide high school arts competition sponsored by the Congressional Institute. The Congressional Art Competition is a way to recognize the talent of young artists here in the Second Congressional District of South Carolina and across the nation. This competition is open to all high school students, and one winner is selected to represent the Second District. The winning artwork will be displayed for one year in the U.S. Capitol along with art from all participating districts around the country. This is truly a spectacular exhibit - one that I encourage all to come and see if you are ever in Washington.     More information on how to enter and competition guidelines can be found here.   Sincerely, Member Of Congress                     Washington, DC Office1436 Longworth House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515phone: (202) 225-2452fax: (202) 225-2455   The Midlands Office1700 Sunset Blvd (US 378), Suite 1West Columbia, SC 29169phone: (803) 939-0041fax: (803) 939-0078   Aiken/Barnwell Office1930 University Parkway, Suite 1600Aiken, SC 29801phone: (803) 642-6416fax: (803) 642-6418                     Unsubscribe | Privacy   Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window  Click here to open a plain text version of this email

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }         News from Representative Sires                                         Last week in Washington, the House passed critical reforms for the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) and expanded essential labor rights. I met with leaders on education and labor policy to inform my legislative work and attended hearings with my colleagues on the House Foreign Affairs Committee.   Legislation Meetings  Foreign Affairs  Legislation  Last Tuesday, the House considered a bill that I cosponsored, H.R. 2382, the USPS Fairness Act, introduced by Rep. Peter DeFazio (D-OR). In 2006, the United States Postal Service was required to be the only government agency to pre-fund health care for all employees present and future. In the changing landscape of distribution in the following 14 years, I believe, along with many of my colleagues, that this is an unsustainable burden on of our nation’s most important public services. I voted in favor of H.R. 2382, which would repeal the 2006 mandate and passed on a bipartisan vote of 309-106.  Last Thursday, I voted in favor of H. Res.826, a bill expressing disapproval of the Administration’s Medicaid block grant proposal, introduced by Rep. Marc Veasey (D-TX). It is critical to protect Medicaid recipients against any efforts to undermine or reduce coverage, especially in the face of rising health care and prescription drug costs. H.Res.826 passed by a vote 223-190. Later that day, I also voted for another bill that I cosponsored, H.R. 2474, the Protecting the Right to Organize Act of 2019, introduced by Rep. Bobby Scott (D-VA). As inequality in our economy spikes, the rights of workers to organize and protect themselves must be guarded at all costs. H.R. 2474 protects the right to strike, the right to act in solidarity with workers at other companies, the right to pursue justice through class action, and other fundamental rights.  This bill also strengthens the ability of workers to negotiate for higher wages, better benefits, and secure first contract agreements. H.R. 2474 passed by a vote of 224-194.  Crucially, the House also passed H.R. 5687, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Disaster Relief and Puerto Rico Disaster Tax Relief Act, introduced by Rep. Nita Lowey (D-NY). This package provides $4.67 billion in emergency supplemental aid for Puerto Rico following a series of intense earthquakes in recent months. I voted in favor of this package and will continue working with my colleagues to help Puerto Rico rebuild.  H.R. 5687 passed by a vote of 237-161. All of the bills passed this week have been sent to the Senate for consideration. Meetings  Last Wednesday, I met with representatives of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers. We discussed my support for labor unions and the work Congress is currently undertaking to progress labor rights across the country. The following day, I met with the National Education Association. Speaking with NEA Director Donna Mirabelli and New Jersey Director Anita Kober, we went over legislative priorities for protecting our public schools and expanding funding to ensure the success of students. Afterwards, I spoke at “Dominicans on the Hill” day, an event hosted by my friend Rep. Adriano Espaillat (D-NY). I am thrilled every year to meet with the constituents who travel to Washington and am proud to be a longtime supporter of the Dominican community.  Foreign Affairs   I attended a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing on Wednesday focused on the challenges facing women in global health. As Chairman of the Western Hemisphere Subcommittee, I was proud to bring the knowledge my Subcommittee colleagues and I have fostered on women’s health issues to the full Committee hearing. When I visited the Venezuela-Colombia border, I spoke directly with Venezuelan women about their concerns for the health and safety of them and their children. Sheba Crocker, Vice President for Humanitarian Policy and Practice at the relief agency CARE, emphasized how the stories I heard firsthand represent the prevalence of gender-based violence, stemming in part from the Venezuela crisis. Congress must always look to lift up marginalized voices in the creation of our foreign policy and work to overcome challenges women face in global health.   As Latvia will celebrate the 30th anniversary of independence from the Soviet Union later this year, I met with Rihards Kols, Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee for the Latvian Saeima, and Reinis Znotins, Chairman of the IT and Innovative Entrepreneurship Subcommittee. I emphasized my commitment to combating Russian aggression and we discussed how a Belarus travel ban could make the country more susceptible to Russian influence. On Thursday, I sat down with Metin Hakverdi, a member of the German Bundestag, to express our mutual support for a strong U.S.- German relationship. Also last Thursday, I met with Juan Guaidó, Venezuela’s Interim President, along with Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other House colleagues. Nearly 5 million Venezuelans have been forced to flee their homes due to a humanitarian crisis caused by Nicolás Maduro. I spoke with President Guaidó about how to bolster our international aid response and promote democratic elections in Venezuela. Additionally, I voiced my support for granting Temporary Protected Status (TPS) to protect Venezuelans already here in the U.S. Last Friday, I met with Taiwan’s Vice President Elect, Lai Ching-te, along with some of my colleagues on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. We discussed Taiwan’s recent election, Taiwan’s response to the coronavirus, and the U.S-Taiwan partnership.  Thank you for reading the Washington Review. Again, hearing from my constituents enables me to be a better representative of the 8th District. For regular updates, you may stay in touch by leaving comments on my Facebook, Twitter, and website.        Sincerely,Albio SiresMember of Congress                  Washington, DC Office 2342 Rayburn HOB Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-7919 Jersey City Office 257 Cornelison Ave. Suite 4408 Jersey City, NJ 07302 Phone: 201-309-0301 Elizabeth Office 800 Anna Street Elizabeth, NJ 07201 Phone: 908-820-0692 West New York Office 5500 Palisade Avenue, Suite A West New York, NJ 07093 Phone: 201-558-0800           Unsubscribe | Privacy  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }             News from Representative Steve Womack          HOME   |   ABOUT STEVE   |   SERVICES   |   3RD DISTRICT   |   ISSUES & LEGISLATION   |   NEWSROOM       February 14, 2020    WEEK IN REVIEW To start off this week’s From the Front… I would like to thank all of the Arkansans who stopped by my Washington office during their visits to our nation’s capital, including Steven and Tawnie Rowell of Cabot. Safe travels back to the Natural State! The House convened and voted on a series of bills, including the Homeland Security for Children Act (), the DHS Acquisition Reform Act of 2019 (), the providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2546) to designate certain lands in the State of Colorado as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the joint resolution () removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment; and for other purposes. (), the Smithsonian Women's History Museum Act (), the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act (), and the removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment (). Budget season has officially begun. Earlier this week, I received the President’s budget request for Fiscal Year 2021. While Congress holds the Article I powers of the Constitution, or the “power of the purse,” the President’s budget outlines his vision for the nation. The release of the President’s budget request historically kicks off the congressional budget process in both the House and the Senate. It serves as a starting point for lawmakers to make spending decisions and analyze the economic outlook for the coming year. The framework of the budget process can be divided up into :   President submits the budget to Congress House and Senate mark up and pass budget House and Senate conference the budget resolution Consideration and passage of Appropriations bills Consideration of reconciliation/authorization Start of new Fiscal Year (October 1st)   I applaud President Trump for putting forward a budget proposal. That’s more than we can say for the People’s House, where, for the second straight year, the Democrat majority has failed to produce a budget. That’s not leadership.  This is interesting to me because, on the House Budget Committee majority’s website, there is a section titled “Responsibility.” The first sentence in this section reads, “The Committee’s chief responsibility is to draft an annual concurrent resolution on the budget that provides a congressional framework for spending and revenue levels, the federal surplus or deficit, and public debt.”  In every business, in every city, in every state, a budget is done. Yet, here in the House, in the greatest country in the world, we’re not doing a budget. Simply put, a failure to budget is a failure to govern.  We must start doing our job to put our country on a sustainable, responsible fiscal path. This is our duty to the American people, not promoting budget-busting policies, including Medicare-for-All and the Green New Deal, that will leave future generations saddled with the consequences of House Democrats’ eagerness to spend with no way to pay. It’s time for Democrats to stop punting one of our most basic responsibilities in Congress. I’m ready for them to join us at the table to do the difficult work.  While we can’t analyze the Democrats’ budget – because they won’t put one forth – the House Budget Committee did hold a hearing on the President’s FY 2021 budget proposal with OMB Acting Director Russell Vought. As we discussed, the proposal seeks to balance our fiscal constraints with the need to fund the priorities of the country, including national defense. The President’s budget includes deficit reduction measures, specifically $4.6 trillion between 2021-2030. This is a strong start, but more work remains to be done to put our country on a solid fiscal path. Moving forward, it is imperative that we work together in a bipartisan, bicameral fashion to advance a budget that funds our nation’s important priorities while acknowledging our very real fiscal challenges. You can read my full opening remarks .  MEETINGS  In between votes and legislative business, I also had the opportunity to meet with organizations from the Natural State! It was a pleasure to meet with Keturah Finch and Tanner Arnwine of Bentonville to talk about neurofibromatosis (NF), a genetic, tumor-generating disorder. We discussed research through the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program (CDMRP) and the National Institutes of Health, as well as its value to civilians, warfighters, and veterans suffering from NF. Novel research has led to a new era of medical breakthroughs for a variety of illnesses, but there is still much more work to be done across many fields. We must continue to make smart investments that build our pipeline of science, research, and medical discovery. The next morning, I invited my Republican House Budget Committee colleagues to join me at the Office of Budget and Management to hear more about the President’s recently released budget proposal, as well as fiscal priorities of the White House. As I mentioned earlier, I appreciate the Administration for drafting a budget. Congress should be doing the same thing, but House Democrats have refused to put forth a proposal yet again. In the real world, everyday Americans and Arkansans are held accountable for their income, expenses, and savings. Main Street job creators and business leaders are held accountable for demonstrating fiscal restraint, for making tough choices, and for setting priorities. Congress should not be any different. But in the House, Democrats are refusing to put forth the very document that tells us what we need to know about how much we’re spending, what we’re raising in revenue, and the impact of our deficits and debt on our economy and the nation. The American people deserve better.  Representatives from NorthWest Arkansas Community College (NWACC) were in Washington, and I had the opportunity to hear some important school and curriculum updates. We talked about enhancing Career and Technical Education (CTE), the Fostering Undergraduate Talent by Unlocking Resources for Education (FUTURE) Act – which I voted for – and the National Science Foundation’s Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program. NWACC just received an ATE grant for a project that will create a Technical Certificate in Integrated Design to help expand the skilled technical workforce, especially in construction fields and engineering design. NWACC is helping prepare our students for the jobs of today and the future, and I appreciate their dedication to providing quality education and opportunities in the Third District. I thank Dr. Evelyn Jorgenson, Dr. Ricky Tompkins, Jim Hall, Rachel Harris, and DeAnne Witherspoon for their time and work!  I then met with the Arkansas Fraternal Order of Police. I always appreciate meeting with our law enforcement officers and hearing more about their work to protect and serve our communities. We discussed many issues, including The Protect and Serve Act (HR 1325). I’m a cosponsor of this legislation, which creates new federal penalties for individuals who deliberately attack or attempt to cause significant bodily injury to any law enforcement officer. This bill aims to deter attacks against police officers who have increasingly been targeted and face higher levels of hostility because of the uniform they wear. I’m extremely thankful for the work of the men and women who wear the badge each day!  My next meeting was with the Enlisted Association of the Arkansas National Guard. It was wonderful to sit down with Arkansas National Guard members from Fort Smith and other parts of the state to talk about their work, duties, and programs that support their efforts. We also had a productive discussion on the National Guard’s role going forward in the Space and Cyber domains. The Arkansas Air National Guard has both Space and Cyber missions. As a 30-year veteran of the Arkansas Army National Guard, I salute their service and thank them for their commitment to the Natural State and our nation! I then welcomed Dr. John Lorsch, Director of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, to my office to speak about the Institutional Development Award (IDea) program and its impact on Arkansas. Our conversations focused on the NIH’s research and biomedical investments within the Natural State.  I wrapped up the day at the National Guard Association, where I joined National Guard members from across the country to talk about defense efforts, legislative advocacy, and my work on the House Budget Committee. I shared stories about my time in uniform, as well as my perspectives on appropriations work in Congress. I talked about the constrained resource environment we face, and how growing mandatory spending is squeezing the portion of discretionary funding available for national priorities. The Guard brings great value to the fight, and it was my honor to talk to this great group and answer questions.  The next morning, I met with Dan Hendrix, President and CEO of the World Trade Center Arkansas. I appreciated an update on their work, economic development in the community, small business grants, and the impact of recent trade deals on the state. Arkansas is a state of opportunity, and the World Trade Center Arkansas is a pivotal resource that has supported bilateral trade services, global connections, and export development programs for local businesses.  Our region is full of opportunity, and it was great to speak with students from the Future Leaders Exchange (FLEX) program. FLEX students spend an academic year in the U.S. living with a volunteer host family and attending high school. The students, who are from Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, are currently living and going to school in Russellville and Springdale! They said that they have learned a lot during their time living and studying in the region – and that they love the sense of community in Arkansas!    Modernized infrastructure is vital to keeping our communities economically competitive and strong. It was great to wrap up my week in Washington with Department of Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao. We had very productive conversations on rural infrastructure grants, local projects like I-49 and regional airport improvements, and budget and appropriations. We also highlighted the importance of addressing U.S. infrastructure needs using smart and effective methods that provide results and maximize our resources. Today, I also want to wish everyone – especially my wonderful wife, Terri – a Happy Valentine’s Day! I'm grateful that my office was able to present some special valentines to residents at Methodist Village Senior Living in Fort Smith. Spreading some cheer and happiness is what this day is all about! I’m looking forward to being back in the district and traveling the Natural State next week. Wishing everyone a Happy Presidents’ Day on Monday! Let us reflect and honor the leaders who've held our nation's highest office to serve the American people. By swearing an oath to “preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States,” they each answered the call to lead our great country throughout history. From George Washington to Donald Trump, Happy Presidents' Day to all our leaders – past and present!  Remember to keep an eye on my  or check out my Twitter and Instagram pages to stay up-to-date with the latest news from the Third District and Washington.     From the front... body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                                       Dear Friends, This week, I introduced H.R. 5863, the Student Loan Marriage Penalty Elimination Act. This legislation addresses growing student loan debt by making the student loan interest tax deduction work better for married couples. Current law penalizes married couples by only allowing them to take one deduction—even if both spouses qualify. This bill would stop this unfair tax on student loans against married couples while also helping individuals with their student loan debt burden. For decades, hardworking Americans have been saddled with student loan debt which has delayed their dreams of achieving financial stability. I am proud to lead this effort to maximize the student loan interest tax deduction that married couples can claim each tax year. This allows married couples to put more towards paying off their student loans, incur less interest, put more food on the table, or save a little more for a down payment on a home. This unfair marriage penalty came to my attention after Claudia McHale, a constituent from Garden City, discussed with me the situation of her niece and her husband. Both of them paid towards reducing their student loan yet were only able to claim a $2,500 deduction between the two of them, the same maximum amount a single individual can claim every tax year. As Claudia said, “it is ridiculous that the federal government punishes taxpayers with student loan balances just because they get married.”                                                   __________  On Tuesday, I received the True Blue Award from the Family Research Council. This recognition is awarded to Members of Congress with a proven record of defending the right to life, religious freedoms, and family values.   It is truly an honor to represent Missouri's 4th congressional district as we fight for our foundational values.  Legislative Update On Thursday, Democrat leadership in the House attempted resurrect the 1972 Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) through Congress.  I commend the women who have gone before us, to celebrate the achievements women have made, and to reaffirm the fact that we are already equal in the eyes of God and in law. Women make up 51% of the population, comprise over half of college students, make up most of today’s medical and law school students, and own the majority of new businesses. Little girls can be whatever they want to be whether that be an astronaut, a doctor, a full-time mom working at home, or a Member of Congress.  In addition, federal law and court precedent uphold our rights. That is something to applaud and I do.  However, today’s legislation is problematic on several fronts. First, the resolution is unconstitutional. The time limit to pass the ERA expired decades ago. Congress can’t go back and remove a deadline from a previous constitutional amendment initiative. The Supreme Court has recognized that the 1972 ERA expired, and the Department of Justice issued a ruling saying, “Congress may not revive a proposed amendment after a deadline for its ratification has expired.” Pretending we can remove the time limits for passage is both futile and deceptive. Secondly, if the time limit COULD be extended, the ERA would not bring women any more rights than they currently have but it would entrench the legality of abortion. We know this from court precedent and by listening to those who have the most to gain from constitutionally protecting abortion on demand.  In 1998, the New Mexico Supreme Court ruled that the Equal Rights Amendment in their state constitution requires state-funding of abortions. Federal courts are likely to do the same. Perhaps this is why every major pro-abortion organization is endorsing passage of the ERA.  NARAL Pro-Choice America says: “With its ratification, the ERA would reinforce the constitutional right to abortion….” National Organization for Women: “An ERA—properly interpreted—could negate the hundreds of laws that have been passed restricting access to abortion care.…” But that’s not the only concern with passing this resolution. Besides being unconstitutional and shredding state and federal pro-life protections, the ERA would also erase decades of progress which have provided opportunities for women, advanced women’s progress through federal programs, and secured necessary protections for women and girls. How? By incorporating gender identity in the definition of ‘sex’, jeopardizing private spaces for women, girls’ sports programs, and women’s educational institutions.  By banning distinctions between men and women, the ERA also endangers laws, programs and funding designed to benefit women. The ERA provides a pathway for legal challenges to welfare programs, grants for battered women’s shelters, efforts to bolster women participating in STEM programs. These outcomes of the ERA are anything but pro-woman. I urge my colleagues to vote ‘No’ on today’s resolution and uphold the Constitution, promote life, and protect women’s rights that have been so hard-fought gained.  District Update I am so pleased to tell you about an honor recently won by Columbia Public Schools. Project Tomorrow is a national education nonprofit dedicated to ensuring that today’s students are well prepared to be tomorrow’s innovators, leaders, and engaged citizens of the world. Project Tomorrow is recognizing Columbia Public Schools with its annual Speak Up District of Honor award, an honor given to school districts for leadership and commitment to listening to the voices and views of students, parents, and educators.    I believe it is through these valuable exchanges that better learning experiences are created for students from kindergarten through the 12th grade. Congratulations to Columbia Public Schools for earning this distinction and for its dedication to improving and enhancing the educational experience for its students.  Constituent Update I want to share with you that our office has joined forces with the Library of Congress to help preserve, forever, the stories of our veterans.   The Veterans History Project began as an effort to collect the accounts of America’s World War II heroes, many of whom are passing away without their stories being saved for posterity. It has since expanded to veterans of all military encounters with the goal of ensuring their personal memories are recorded and made available for future generations. If you are a veteran or if you know a veteran who would like to share your experiences as part of the Veterans History Project, contact Steve Walsh in our Columbia office at 573-442-9311. Every time I step on the House floor, I’m focused on legislation that will help our district - whether that’s lowering out of pocket health care costs or making sure every student gets a quality education. No matter what is happening in Washington, I won’t lose sight of the issues we face back home.  I was especially lucky to introduce Kathy Zeman to the House Agriculture Committee earlier this week. Kathy farms in Rice County and she came to Washington to testify in support of the Local Agricultural Markets Program which promotes farmers’ markets around the country.         Expanding Higher Ed Opportunities  On Tuesday, I spoke with Minnesota State about how we can expand higher ed opportunities for our students. If education isn’t affordable, it’s not accessible.         Improving Rural Health CareRight now, there are insufficient health care resources in our rural communities. Wednesday, I met with folks from the Minnesota Department of Health to talk about the unique healthcare challenges facing rural patients and providers.       Advocating for Minnesota River Funding This week, I sat down with the Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, and the Waterways Council to discuss the importance of the Minnesota River Dredging project in keeping the river fully operational. The river transports about 4 million tons annually, worth more than $362 Million in economic value.         Pushing for Ratification of the ERA: Equal rights for women should not have a deadline. In fact, it’s long past time. That’s why I voted to remove the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment on Thursday.  Protecting Medicare, Medicaid, and Social SecurityThe President’s budget proposes cuts to Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security. I’ll never stand for that. Watch my video about these cuts here.   Supporting the Special OlympicsThis week was Special Olympics Hill Day! It was great meeting with our Minnesota delegation about empowering folks with different abilities.       Meeting Rescue PuppiesThursday, I stopped by the ASPCA Paws for Love pet adoption event to give out some belly rubs.         Funding Recreational TrailsThis week, I introduced the Recreational Trails Full Funding Act of 2020 with Rep. Welch to make sure folks have quality trails to enjoy Minnesota’s four seasons for hiking, cross country skiing and taking their ATV’s out. Not only will this bill invest in these opportunities right now, but it also makes sure future generations of Minnesotans and visitors can experience the beauty of the Minnesota River Valley and our well-traveled trails from Zumbrota to Cottage Grove.   Upcoming Event:Excited to announce my February town hall! I hope you can join me on Feb. 19th in Savage          Sincerely,   Angie CraigMember of Congress           Washington, DC Office 1523 Longworth House Office Building Washington, DC Phone: (202) 225-2271   Burnsville, MN Office 12940 Harriet Avenue South Suite 238 Burnsville, MN Phone: (651) 846-2120         Open in browser window        Open plain text version    Unsubscribe

body: Conaway Chronicle: Announcing Academy Day __________________________________________ Thank you for reading The Conaway Chronicle, a review of my activities in Congress and the 11th District. Announcing Academy Day I will be hosting a Military Service Academy Day on March 7th in San Angelo, assisted by the offices of U.S. Senators John Cornyn (R-TX) and Ted Cruz (R-TX). This event provides students, parents, counselors, and educators the opportunity to learn about the Service Academy nomination process and meet with representatives from each of the service academies, Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC), and participating congressional offices. Attendance is highly encouraged for high school freshmen, sophomores, and juniors who are interested in applying for a service academy. I am honored to have one last opportunity to oversee the military academy nomination process as a Member of Congress. Over the years, Joanne Powell in my San Angelo office has been a champion for these students, and her mentorship has helped many of the 11th Districts finest earn acceptance into academies of their choice. I am extremely proud of every one of the brave women and men who I have had the honor of nominating in the past, and I am looking forward to working with the applicants this year. WHAT: Military Service Academy Day WHEN: Saturday, March 7th from 1:00 to 4:30 p.m. WHERE: Angelo State University, CJ Davidson Conference Center 1910 Rosemont Dr. San Angelo, TX More information regarding the Academy nomination process can be found here. Thank you for reading. It is the honor of a lifetime to serve the people of the 11th District, and I look forward to continuing to work on your behalf. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to call, write, or email. To keep up with my ongoing work in Congress and the 11th District, please follow along on on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Sincerely, Rep. Mike Conaway, 11th District Unsubscribe:

I am proud to announce that I have secured significant funding to start construction on the Arkansas Valley Conduit, which will provide clean drinking water for 50,000 Coloradans in 40 communities. This is the first time funding has been secured since Congress authorized the project and President Kennedy promised completion nearly six decades ago. The communities of the Lower Arkansas Valley deserve clean drinking water, which the Arkansas Valley Conduit will supply for generations to come. This is the first time robust federal funding of $28 million has been dedicated to the project which will help finish final design, pre-construction costs, and begin construction to get to the first community in need. In Pueblo last week I celebrated the good news with members of the Southeastern Colorado Water Conservancy District and discussed the next steps on the project. Read more from the Pueblo Chieftain.  Learn More About My Guest to the State of the Union Address   Click here or the picture above to watch remarks from Senator Gardner and his State of the Union guest Kristen Christy on destigmatizing mental health.  I’m honored that Kristen Christy, the 2018 Air Force Spouse of the Year, attended the State of the Union Address as my guest. Kristen has experienced heartbreaking loss that no family should ever have to face. Through her strength and commitment to military families, Kristen has become an inspiring suicide prevention advocate and guiding light for the Air Force and entire military community as she helps others transition from post-traumatic stress to post-traumatic growth. Her resilience, courage, and her never-quit attitude exemplify the best of the American spirit, and it’s fitting that someone with her inspirational and moving story was in the room as the president highlighted the progress and opportunities for our great country. Meeting with Fort Carson Officials About Infrastructure Improvements and the Novel Coronavirus  I recently visited Fort Carson and received an update on Gate 19 construction and infrastructure improvement projects both on base and in the community. We also discussed the possibility of evacuees from the novel coronavirus outbreak being quarantined at Fort Carson. I appreciate the leadership on base that is organized and ready if needed to assist our nation's response and containment of this virus. I wrote to leaders on the Senate Appropriations Committee requesting that they work with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to ensure robust funding to respond to the novel coronavirus outbreak. As the novel coronavirus continues to spread around the world, HHS, through a number of its agencies, is actively leading critical prevention, containment, and supply chain stability efforts. Congress must serve as a collaborative partner and ensure that there is sufficient funding for both current and potential future efforts to contain this communicable and deadly virus. Meeting with the Fort Collins Chamber of Commerce  I recently had a great discussion with the Fort Collins Chamber of Commerce Legislative Affairs Committee on water policy, transportation and housing issues, and ways we can work together to grow the economy and boost job creation in Colorado. I always enjoy meeting with Coloradans to gain their input on a variety of issues and help bring more of Colorado to Washington.  New Renovations at the Colorado Springs Airport    I had a great visit at the Colorado Springs Airport to discuss renovations and growth, including plans for a new airtanker base and ramp to support firefighting efforts. Year after year, much of the West is forced to deal with horrible wildfires that burn millions of acres. Our firefighters risk everything to protect our communities and it's our duty to make sure they have every possible tool to safely fight wildfires. This new airtanker base will serve as an incredible resource for firefighters in Colorado and surrounding areas. Providing Student Loan Relief for Colorado Students In November, the Department of Education announced it would cancel the loans taken out by students to attend the Art Institute of Colorado between January 20, 2018 – when the school lost its accreditation – and December 31, 2018 – when they shut their doors. Senator Michael Bennet (D-CO) and I urged Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos to extend the school discharge eligibility period because the relief is incomplete and does not relieve students of the debt they took on to attend the school prior to January 20, 2018, which is now worthless. At our urging, the Department of Education agreed to expand student loan forgiveness for those who attended the Art Institute of Colorado at the time the school lost its accreditation, meaning more Colorado students will receive full relief on federal loans still owed, as well as a refund of loans they have already paid.  Supporting Sugar Beet Farmers After Adverse Weather Conditions The past two years have been devastating for Cooperative farmers working in Colorado, Montana, Nebraska, and Wyoming due to significant weather events. In 2018 and 2019, growing regions across these states experienced freezing temperatures in early October before sugar beets are typically harvested. I sent a bipartisan letter with Senator Michael Bennet (D-CO) and a bipartisan group of our colleagues urging U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue to take immediate action in implementing the sugar beet eligibility provisions that were passed in the Fiscal Year 2020 Appropriations bill as part of the Wildfire, Hurricane, and Indemnity Program Plus (WHIP+). This program has been essential for farmers during adverse weather growing seasons, and USDA’s swift action is necessary in order for farmers to obtain operating loans for the 2020 crop.  Meeting Taiwan’s Vice President-Elect Lai Ching-te  I was honored to meet with Taiwan’s Vice President-elect Lai Ching-te recently and reaffirm that the U.S. Congress will continue to advocate on behalf of Taiwan as guided by U.S. law, including the Taiwan Relations Act, the Taiwan Travel Act, and my Asia Reassurance Initiative Act. I also relayed my concerns with the World Health Organization excluding Taiwan as the novel coronavirus spreads around the globe. As China continues its aggressive campaign to delegitimize Taiwan, it’s critically important for the U.S. to reaffirm our support for Taiwan. I have offices in Denver, Durango, Pueblo, Grand Junction, Fort Collins, Greeley, Yuma, and Colorado Springs. Learn more about how we can help here.   Thank you for taking the time to read my weekly update. body: Check it out here.       Congratulations Ms. Musgrove!   I was proud to recognize Kristen Musgrove, a sixth grade math teacher at Hilliard Middle-Senior High School, for receiving the prestigious Milken Educator Award! Please click here to watch my floor speech honoring her achievement.  Under her instruction, her classes lead the Nassau County school district with a 97% math proficiency rate. Her dedication to her students also extends beyond the classroom as she offers tutoring at a weekly after-school math camp. On behalf of the Fourth District of Florida and the grateful students and parents of Hilliard Middle-Senior High School, I want to thank Ms. Musgrove for her lifelong dedication to excellence in the classroom. Congratulations on receiving the recognition you so well deserve.       Bipartisan Mental Health Legislation I joined a bipartisan group of representatives to introduce the Crisis Stabilization and Community Reentry Act of 2020. This bipartisan legislation helps local law enforcement partner with community-based mental health providers to ensure incarcerated individuals transition successfully back into society.   When I served as Director of Corrections in Duval County, I knew the prison system was the largest residential mental health facility in Northeast Florida. We learned that we were able to reduce recidivism by offering inmates continued care after their release from prison. Today’s legislation enhances coordination between law enforcement officials and mental health professionals by authorizing federal grants to provide treatment options for individuals with mental illness as they transition from incarceration back into the community.  To learn more about this bill, please click here.         Snapshot: Recent Photo Highlights   I was thrilled to meet with Special Olympians and their wonderful advocates including WWE legend The Big Show!  Click here to see more photos on my Instagram!     Stay Connected As your voice in Washington, it is important that I hear from you.
