subject: A Busy Week, & The Start of a Months-Long Budget Process
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }         News from Representative Courtney                                                 Dear Cormack,  Following a busy week in Washington, here with a few updates on several priorities for eastern Connecticut.    Honoring Those Lost on 10th Anniversary of Kleen Energy Explosion  Last Friday marked ten years since the tragic explosion at the Kleen Energy Systems power plant in Middletown. The blast injured dozens of workers, and it took the lives of six: Peter Chepulis, Raymond Dobratz, Kenneth Haskell, Roy Rushton, Chris Walters, and one of my close friends, Ron Crabb. On Sunday, I was in Middletown along with colleagues, community leaders, and friends and family of those who were lost in the tragic accident, to honor and remember those who never came home that day. Ten years ago, workplace safety laws failed these six individuals, and the dozens of others who were injured in the blast. Nothing can ever make up for the lives lost that day, but we have a responsibility as a community and as a Congress to ensure we do all we can to protect America’s workers. Last year, on the 9th anniversary of the explosion, I introduced the Protecting America’s Workers Act (PAWA) to strengthen and modernize the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 (OSHA) – which hasn’t been meaningfully updated by Congress in over 50 years. The bill is simple, and contains some common-sense measures like improving whistleblower protections; requiring the federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) to investigate all cases of death and series injuries that occur within a place of employment; and establishing rights for families of workers who were killed on the job by giving them the right to meet with OSHA investigators, receive copies of citations, and more. The lives lost ten years ago deserve to be honored with action. To read how PAWA makes workplaces safer, click here to visit my website.        Rep. Courtney joined community leaders, friends, and families at a memorial service for those lost in the Kleen Energy explosion     Bipartisan Action on Surprise Health Care Billing  Surprise medical bills are a crisis waiting to happen for so many families in eastern Connecticut and across the country. When people are ill, the last thing they should have to worry about is how to safeguard themselves against complex billing technicalities that result in surprise, sky-high medical bills. The cost of health care is a top-line issue for folks in our region, and surprise billing is a major contributor – my office has received far too many calls from people in eastern Connecticut who have not been treated fairly.  We’ve already taken steps in the House to curb the cost of prescription medication, and this week we took on surprise billing. On Tuesday, my colleagues and I on the house Education & Labor Committee voted to approve the bipartisan Ban Surprise Billing Act (H.R. 5800), a bill that would protect patients from devastating surprise medical bills, and would finally give them the financial confidence and peace of mind they deserve. These protections would be for everyone – for people who receive health care through their employer, and for those who are enrolled in the individual market. Erica Moser did a great job covering the ins and outs of the bill in her article for The Day, click here to read more. One of the most exciting parts about H.R. 5800 is that it’s so bipartisan – it was supported by both the Democratic Chairman of the Committee, and by the Republican Ranking Member. People in Congressional Districts across America are impacted by surprise medical bills, and it’s great to see Members from both sides of the aisle coming together to address the problem. I commend Chairman Scott and Ranking Member Foxx for working together to advance this bipartisan bill, I was proud to support it, and I’m looking forward to voting to pass it when it comes before the House for a final vote.        Click here to watch Rep. Courtney's remarks in favor of H.R. 5800     Meeting with National Defense University Students  On Tuesday, I hosted a large group of students from the National Defense University’s Eisenhower School to discuss some of the top priorities on the horizon for our Armed Forces and the industrial base, and to learn more about their work as students focusing on undersea warfare. As always, these NDU students were totally impressive – they came to study in Washington from all across the U.S., represented a variety of branches, backgrounds, agencies, and experiences, and were sharp and well informed on our national security strategy and priorities.   Our conversation turned in large part to the flurry of activity we’ve seen in Connecticut’s defense manufacturing sector recently. Up and down the supply chain, skilled manufacturers and small companies are seeing new opportunities for work. Connecticut’s defense manufacturing is booming, but even that good news presents its own challenges – mainly, how can we make sure that we have a workforce that’s skilled and well educated enough to take advantage of these new opportunities? The answer to that question has been the Eastern Connecticut Workforce Investment Board’s revolutionary job skills training program, the Manufacturing Pipeline Initiative (MPI). The MPI was kick-started with a $6 million federal grant that I helped to procure back in 2015, and since then it’s flourished alongside our state’s burgeoning manufacturing sector. The MPI has helped Electric Boat (EB) to grow by thousands of employees in just a few short years. In the last year alone, EB reported that they made over 1,000 hires directly from the pipeline. The MPI is exactly what was needed to fill the ranks of a booming manufacturing sector, and its been a total success for our region. It was great to host this impressive class of National Defense University students in Washington this week, and to discuss with them all of the moving parts that must work in unison to deliver the tools are Navy and Armed Forces need.        Students from the National Defense University met with Rep. Courtney at his Washington, DC office       The Start of a Months-Long Budget Process   Earlier this week, the White House released their official 2021 budget request. Ultimately it is Congress’s job to craft and pass a budget through the House and the Senate, and it’s the President's job to sign it. However, the start of the budget negotiation process typically begins with the White House’s budget request – their “proposed budget” – and this year we’re off to a strange start.  The White House’s proposed budget makes $1.1 trillion in cuts to Medicaid, Medicare and other health care programs over the next 10 years. It also slashes investments that help workers find and keep good paying jobs, and altogether eliminates bedrock programs that help fund America’s public education system. Thankfully, this is just the start of a months-long budget negotiation process. The proposed budget introduced by the White House yesterday has already received criticism from both sides of the aisle, and it’s not going to make it through Congress as-is. It’s not encouraging to see the White House kick the process off with a budget proposal that points so many important programs in the wrong direction, but as the House moves into our own budget negotiating process, we have an opportunity to work together across the aisle to get it right. It will remain our top priority in the House to protect and defend the health, financial security, and well-being of millions of Americans as we begin debate on the 2021 budget.      Proposed Shipbuilding Budget Receives Bipartisan Criticism  One of the components of the 2021 budget request that has generated significant bipartisan concern is the plan to cut back on shipbuilding investment for our Navy. Congress had traditionally worked together to provide strong support for the Navy’s plans to build, modernize and support a strong fleet of ships, submarines, destroyers and other vessels critical to our national defense. Contrary to expectations, however, the budget we received this week took a significant step backwards – proposing to purchase just 7 ships, a sharp reduction from the 10 that the Trump Administration itself planned for this year and a nearly 20% reduction in the budget for shipbuilding. Incredibly, one of the cuts included the reduction of a Virginia-class submarine, with only one requested in 2021. This plan flies in the face of more than a decade of testimony from our defense leaders about the unmatched value of our submarine force and increasing alarm about shortfalls in the fleet. It’s even in direct contradiction with the Trump Administration's own plans for our Navy and defense strategy. Given that every submarine we build will be in service for four decades, the decision to plan for only one new submarine next year is short-sighted. As Chairman of the House Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittee, I can say with certainly that this budget is dead on arrival. Throughout the week, bipartisan concern about this proposal has grown across Congress and I am working with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to dig into this surprising plan as we begin our work on the 2021 budget. Click here to read about some of my efforts, and the bipartisan reaction to the budget.        Click here to read Rep. Courtney's bipartisan letter to Secretary Esper     Thank you for taking a moment to read my weekly eNewsletter. It’s an honor every day to represent eastern Connecticut, and I’m grateful that you’ve made my weekly update a part of your weekly routine. I hope you enjoyed this snapshot of my work – if you have any questions or concerns about the information in this newsletter, you can contact me through my website or by calling my Norwich district office at 860-886-0139. The contributions that our great heroes and sheroes – giants like Dr. Martin Luther King, Maya Angelou, and Shirley Chisholm – made to the fight for civil rights and social justice cannot be overstated.    But as we celebrate our progress, we must also take time to reflect on the systemic challenges our communities still face, and how much further we have to go.    African Americans still experience disproportionate levels of poverty, incarceration, and inequality in education and economic opportunities.    That’s why I’m hosting a town hall next Friday to reflect on the work that still needs to be done. We need to protect and expand voting rights so that everyone has a say at the ballot box; get counted in the upcoming Census to ensure everyone is represented in our government; and defeat Trump’s new, cruel budget proposal that would harm our nation’s most vulnerable.  I hope you’ll join me at 6 pm on Friday, February 21, at Beth Eden Family Life Center, located at 1183 10th Street, Oakland, CA 94607. Please RSVP here.   As always, my office is here for you. If you need help with a federal issue, please call my Oakland office at (510) 763-0370. You can also connect with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.    In Solidarity,      Barbara Lee                                                                                                Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window  Click here to open a plain text version of this email  [$$$Survey.2100160$$$]

Not only did I have the joy of seeing these babies when they were delivered, but throughout my career I witnessed great advances in the technology that allowed doctors and parents to see these children developing in the womb. For those of us who have watched a baby squirm and kick during a sonogram, there is no question about the sanctity of life.   While my work has changed through the years – I now spend late nights delivering policy rather than babies – my dedication to pro-life medicine remains steadfast.  The legislation that came before the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health this week would put women's health at risk.  The Women's Health Protection Act of 2019, would codify into law that access to an abortion is essential to women’s health. This is contrary to the Founders of this country who believed in a right to life.     The federal government should work to overcome the factors that lead to abortions and should support well-crafted legislative proposals that directly address these factors. That is not this bill.  MY WEEK President Trump delivered his budget to Congress. In line with his State of the Union address, the Best is Yet to Come, this is a budget for America’s future. It lays the foundation to balance the budget over the next 15 years by stopping unnecessary spending. The budget continues the President’s priorities to rebuild our military, secure our borders, protect our economy, and remain energy independent.   I joined Government CIO to discuss the benefits of electronic health records and of AI in health care.  After that I participated in an Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Commerce hearing on autonomous vehicles. Autonomous vehicles will reduce traffic congestion, improve mobility for the elderly and individuals with disabilities, and could significantly improve safety for all who use our roadways.    The Hill published my opinion article about the future of energy policy in America: "A Free Market for a Clean Future."  Yesterday, I attending the visitation for Midshipman Duke Anthony Carrillo of Flower Mound, Texas.  I had the honor to nominate him and his two brothers to a U.S. Service Academy. He was an aspiring young man. May others learn from his example and follow in his footsteps.     POLL OF THE WEEK                                               President Trump released his budget this week. I appreciate that the budget includes additional funds for a border wall, border security and technology, and hiring additional Custom and Border Protection and Immigration and Customs Enforcement law enforcement officers. Do you think the wall should be built on our southern border?  YES  NO  Other (please specify)          CONNECT WITH ME                                                          Washington, DC Office 2161 Rayburn House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-7772 Lake Dallas District Office2000 South Stemmons Freeway, Suite 200Lake Dallas, TX 75065Phone: (940) 497-5031

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                     -->              Dear friends and neighbors,  This week, House Democrats took a stance and fought for the passage of the Equal Rights Amendment (ERA). It is far past time for the women of this country to be included in our nation’s Constitution, and we will continue to fight to ensure no American is treated differently on the basis of gender.  My vote for the ERA was a vote for equality!   Here’s what else I’ve been up to:   Fighting for Working Americans         I had the pleasure of meeting with AFGE Local 556 to discuss the progression of federal employee rights in our country. Federal employees are the backbone of our government, and I am proud to be a part of conversations that aim to advance their rights!    Supporting Our Sheriffs         I also enjoyed meeting with the National Sheriffs’ Association to discuss mental health issues as they relate to the law enforcement systems in our communities. Mental health is extremely important to our collective well being, so I am always eager to discuss ways in which we can improve our services in this area.    Caring for the Blind         This past year, we were able to secure $2.375 million for the Library of Congress E-Readers for the Blind program. I was happy to meet with Florida’s branch of the National Federation of the Blind to discuss how we can increase education and economic opportunities for the blind.    Fighting to Keep Families Together          I had a particularly inspiring meeting with Americans Family United, who stopped by to share their stories with me. Together, we will fight to give people a second chance and keep families united!  Meeting with Our Young People    As the future of our country, it’s inspiring to see young bright students from Polk State so heavily involved in our government. It’s always a pleasure to have a piece of our district here at our Nation’s Capitol!   Thanking Our Nation's Veterans           I celebrated Valentine's Day with the brave men and women who served our nation. It was an honor to drop off hundreds of handmade cards to the Lake Nona VA Medical Center! To all the veterans out there: you are loved and appreciated beyond measure. A special thank you to Ventura, Boggy Creek and Sand Lake Elementary Schools for making the cards.   Supporting Our Veterans         I spent the afternoon at the Veterans Art Competition! It was truly inspiring to see how veterans make art and use creative practices to transform themselves after their service.     Fighting for Clean Water         Access to safe drinking water is a fundamental right. Yet, the Trump Administration is keen on cutting back funding of lead prevention programs, putting Central Floridians at risk. My committee, Energy and Commerce, is fighting to do more to address this national crisis!    Thank you for the opportunity to serve you in Congress! If you haven't already, please Like my Facebook page and follow me on Twitter for the latest updates on my work. Feel free to reach out to my offices in Central Florida or Washington, D.C. to voice your concerns or for help with federal issues.   In Community,Darren SotoMember of Congress                     Washington, DC 1507 Longworth House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-9889Fax: (202) 225-9742 Haines City 620 E Main StreetHaines City, FL 33844(202) 600-0843 | (202) 615-1308Open Wednesday 9AM-5PM Kissimmee 804 Bryan StreetKissimmee, FL 34741Phone: (407) 452-1171 Lake Wales 201 West Central AvenueLake Wales, FL 33853(202) 600-0843 | (202) 615-1308Open Monday and Tuesday 9AM-5PM  Veteran's Affairs Office Lake Nona VA Medical Center13800 Veterans WayAcross the Patriot's BrewOrlando, FL 32827Phone: (202) 322-4476Open 8AM - 4PMEvery 2nd and 4th Friday of the Month Winter Haven 451 3rd St. NWWinter Haven, FL 33881(202) 600-0843 | (202) 615-1308Open Tuesday, Thursday and Friday 9AM - 5PM*Veteran's Hours Wednesdays 9AM - 5PM          Contact Me | Unsubscribe | Privacy

 Shoreline, Supporting Our Veterans and Recognizing Mary McLeod Bethune

It was a very eventful week and I'm excited to tell you about what we accomplished. Here are some highlights:   I was the Grand Marshall for the Ninth Annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade I toured the Indian River Lagoon to see living shorelines and learn more about preserving our environment I attended the signing of the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act by President Trump at the White House I spoke on the House floor in recognition of Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune and her contributions to our community and country  CELEBRATING OUR RACING HISTORY: This weekend I had the honor of serving as the Grand Marshall of this year’s Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade! Since the 1920s, Daytona Beach has been the home of NASCAR, with drivers setting records racing down our beach to the famous North Turn and A1A. This race is an important part of our community’s history and it’s always one of my favorite events every year!    Serving as Grand Marshall at the 9th annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade  CONSERVING OUR SHORELINE: Our beautiful and natural shorelines can co-exist with development when done correctly. Living shorelines and mangroves are important for our communities because they are the best natural barriers against storm surges. Estuaries and mangroves are also important to commercial fisherman. Around 80 percent of them rely on estuaries and mangroves for spawning. I enjoyed touring our local living shorelines to learn more about how conservancies bring free market, volunteering and community based solutions to our community. It's important we maintain our living shorelines to help keep Florida resilient.     Views of our Indian River Lagoon living shoreline  SUPPORTING OUR VETERANS: This week, I went to the White House to see President Trump sign another bill supporting our veterans into law — and this time, it was a bill I co-sponsored! The Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act supports our veterans, helping them find opportunities for jobs in STEM fields when they return to civilian life. I was glad to work on this bill with two fellow Florida congressmen, Senator Marco Rubio and Congressman Neal Dunn, and I was proud to be there as the President signed it into law!    President Trump signing the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act into law RECOGNIZING SERVANT LEADERSHIP: I can't think of anyone better to highlight great servant leadership in our community and our country this Black History Month than our district's very own Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune. Bethune founded and was President of the all African-American girls school in Daytona Beach, which later became Bethune–Cookman University. Bethune selflessly dedicated herself to fighting for the equality and civil rights of all Americans through education and because of her, Florida and America are a better place.  Click below to watch me honor Dr. Bethune on the House floor:    Please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page and following me on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if my team or I can ever be of service. name: Congressman Greg Murphy M.D.
subject: From Congressman Murphy's Desk
body: Latest News Impeachment is finally over After more than four long, divisive and counter-productive months, impeachment is finally over and the president has been rightfully acquittedthe actions of the president did not warrant the charges. Congress has been stuck at a standstill for too long. Having been sworn into Congress only a week prior to the beginning of the impeachment inquiry, I am thankful this storm has passed and I can finally begin the legislative work eastern North Carolinians elected me to do. Congress could and should have been working on issues like healthcare, prescription drugs, border security and more instead of this tiresome and illegitimate impeachment. Hopefully, we can finally get back to tending to the business of the people. Unfortunately, I doubt that will be the case after the petty and partisan theatrics displayed by Speaker Pelosi at the State of the Union address. Bipartisan efforts that would benefit the American people will likely be forgone due to the Speakers disdain for the president and her fear of giving him legislative victories. America deserves better. What's going on with coronavirus? As a physician and member of Congress, I wanted to give you all an update on the status of the coronavirus and how the United States is working to combat its spread. Watch the video below to learn more. Surprise billing There is bipartisan agreement that surprise billing is a major problem for patients and families across America. It desperately needs to be addressed. While Im glad we discussed the best path forward to alleviate the problems of surprise billing during a markup of H.R. 5800 in the House Committee on Education and Labor this week, this legislation is not the right solution to this problem. Even though I couldn't support H.R. 5800 in its entirety, I was glad to improve it with two amendments that were adopted unanimously. As a physician, I'll continue to utilize my expertise on these issues to lower the cost of healthcare and increase patient access to provide Americans with the greatest treatments possible. Watch my opening statement below: Veterans HOPE Act Last week, I was proud to introduce the Veterans HOPE Act to prevent opioid overdose deaths among veterans. Between 2010 and 2016, deaths due to opioid overdose rose by 65% among veterans. During those same years, veteran deaths caused by heroin and synthetic opioids like fentanyl increased by roughly five-fold. Meanwhile, the rate of prescription opioid receipts within three months before death declined by more than 25%, suggesting that opioid overdoses are likely stemming from hard or synthetic drugs, without knowledge of the initial prescriber. To combat this issue, the Veterans HOPE Act would direct the Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs to further investigate deaths caused by heroin and synthetic opioids. Upon conclusion of the study, the Secretary would report findings to the public and Congress and suggest veteran overdose prevention efforts to save lives. As a member of the North Carolina State Assembly, authoring the main legislative actions to combat the opioid crisis in North Carolina was one of my proudest achievements. Now as the U.S. Representative of a Congressional District with the fifth most veterans in America, the Veterans HOPE Act is especially important research to me. The data speaks for itselfveteran deaths caused by non-prescribed opioids like heroin and fentanyl have skyrocketed. But our veterans are more than a statistic. They are sons and daughters, husbands and wives, and fathers and mothers who have selflessly sacrificed so much for our great nation. It is our duty to do all we can to protect them from the dangers of opioid addiction. You can read the bill here. District Highlights George Henry White Commemorative Stamp Act Honored to introduce legislation this week alongside several of my North Carolina colleagues to honor George Henry White of New Bern, a Republican politican and the last black member of Congress during Reconstruction. George Henry White courageously stood up to racial injustice in a hostile time period for African Americans, especially in the South. The cause of Civil Rights in this country was only advanced because of strong and brave leaders like him. It was only fitting that we honor such a historic African American figure during Black History Month. You can read more about his life and legacy here. Walter B. Jones, Jr. Post Office Almost one year after Congressman Walter B. Jones, Jr.'s passing, Im pleased that a bill I introduced in his honor advanced through the House of Representatives. This measure would designate a post office in his hometown of Farmville, the "Walter B. Jones, Jr. Post Office." It was altogether fitting that my first piece of legislation as a member of Congress be a tribute to my predecessor, friend and mentor. Walter cared deeply for the people of eastern North Carolina, especially the Marines who serve at Camp Lejeune, Cherry Point and New River. He epitomized what a public servant stood forhis constituents. I greatly appreciate my colleagues in the North Carolina delegation for unanimously supporting this bill, and I hope the Senate and President Trump will swiftly act to make this bill a law. You can watch my remarks from the House floor in support of the bill below: Christina Koch Returns to Earth Congratulations to Christina Koch for completing her 328 day mission in space! Welcome back to planet Earth! Christina grew up in Jacksonville and attended NC State. Her time aboard the International Space Station set the record for the longest single continuous spaceflight by a female. Such a tremendous accomplishment for North Carolina, the United States of America and all of humanity. Welcome home, Christina! You can read more about her record-breaking flight here. District Work Even though I've been in our nation's capital for the past two weeks, I've met with numerous people and organizations from North Carolina, many of whom are from the Third District. Scroll through the photos below to see some of the people I met. Had a productive discussion about how Congress can impact state and local narcotic issues with Sgt. Kevin Black, Lt. Daniel Duckworth, Sgt. Mike Dawson, Special Agent Joe Barringer and Sgt. Jason Chappell. Enjoyed talking with representatives from the Pulp and Paperworkers' Resource Council. Forestry is such a vital part of the economy in eastern North Carolina. These gentlemen work at International Paper's facility in New Bern. I learned a great deal about this wonderful renewable resource. It was an honor meeting UNC Chapel Hill's Athletic Director, Bubba Cunningham, and other senior athletic department officials. We talked about college athletics and issues relating to student-athlete compensation that are affecting the NCAA. Met with Tom Gentile, President and CEO of Spirit AeroSystems to discuss their business and presence in North Carolina. Such an honor to attend the North Carolina Opportunity Now Summit with President Trump and several of my colleagues from the North Carolina Congressional delegation. Cutting taxes and red tape has helped create jobs and raise wages across every demographic. We have helped stressed areas of our country by raising people out of poverty with jobs and pride. So much better than creating more government dependency. I will continue to support this administration and its pro-growth policies while serving the great people of eastern North Carolina. It was great meeting with Winston Salem Special Olympics athlete, Jennifer Wardlow, and President and CEO of Special Olympics North Carolina, Keith Fishburne. The Special Olympics is a truly fantastic organization. Honored to meet with the Secretary of Agriculture, Sonny Perdue, with several of my colleagues from the North Carolina delegation. Agriculture is extremely important in eastern North Carolina, and recent trade victories like USMCA and the Phase One trade agreement with China are big wins for American farmers. As a physician, I always enjoy discussing how we can improve America's healthcare system. Had a productive discussion with representatives from National Rural Health. Access, equity and quality of healthcare are especially important issues in places like eastern North Carolina. Thanks for reading! Thank you for signing up to receive my newsletter. I would greatly appreciate it if you could forward this to your family and friends so they can receive periodic updates about what's happening in our nation's capital and eastern North Carolina. It's important to me as a U.S. Representative to keep constituents up to date about my position on the issues in DC, achievements made by people from the district and more. If you are not subscribed already, you can click on the link here. If I can ever be of assistance, or you would just simply like to voice your opinion, please contact my office at (202) 225-3415 or visit my website.

Ilhan Omar‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌           FEBRUARY 2020: PATHWAY TO PEACE, PROTECTING ERITREAN ASYLUM,          STANDING UP FOR WORKERS  Dear Friend,  After a busy two weeks in Washington, I’m excited to get back to the district to engage with the constituents I represent. I will be hosting two important community conversations next week to hear more from you all about the issues impacting our community, and share some exciting policy initiatives I’ve been working on. On Tuesday, February 18th, I will be hosting a discussion of my vision for a progressive foreign policy— one that centers on human rights, justice and peace as the pillars of America’s engagement in the world, and makes military action a last resort. And on Thursday, I’ll be hosting a community conversation on the dangerous spread of hate crimes in the United States and how to combat it. We will have a discussion with leaders of different communities on how we can together to battle this common enemy here in Minnesota and nationwide. I look forward to seeing many of you back in the District next week!  In service,    Ilhan Omar Member of Congress    UPCOMING EVENTS Join us for a Community Conversation about my vision for a progressive foreign policy on Tuesday, February 18, 2020, 12:00 - 1:30 PM CST. RSVP on Eventbrite using this link. I will also host a Community Conversation on combating hate on Thursday, February 20, 6:00-8:00 PM CST. RSVP on Eventbrite using this link. For all updates and upcoming events visit our website here. All events are free and open to the public.    Pathway to Peace This week, I introduced a package of seven bills that outline a bold progressive vision to reimagines the country’s approach to foreign policy as one that centers human rights, justice and peace as the pillars of America’s engagement in the world, and makes military action a last resort. I have firsthand experience with how destructive war can be—and I see how our continuous involvement in foreign conflicts is not making our country or our world any safer. I believe that when the United States says it champions human rights, democracy, and peace, we should mean it.   Eritrean Asylum ENSURE Act This administration will stop at nothing to make life painful for people of color seeking a better future. Not only has the President added Eritrea to its latest Muslim Ban, but he is also now threatening to deport Eritreans who have settled here. That’s why I introduced the ENSURE Act to stop the United States from deporting Eritreans fleeing state oppression. The bill places a two-year stay on removals; prohibits the detention of Eritrean nationals during removal procedures; and, requires up-to-date reporting on Eritreans facing imminent removal.   The PRO Act  As a former union member myself, I can attest to the power that workers wield when they exercise their right to organize. That’s why we need the PRO Act, which puts power back in the hands of workers where it belongs. It will address the challenges and attacks that labor unions have been facing for decades that have led to the erosion of wages, a spike in workplace discrimination, and dangerous growth in inequality. Unions don’t only raise wages. They create working class solidarity between workers across gender, race, ethnicity, and religion.    Trump Budget This week, the Budget Committee held a hearing on President Trump’s latest spending proposals. The administration's new budget slashes Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security, and food stamps—while continuing the President’s disastrous tax breaks for the rich and while increasing wasteful spending on endless wars. We need a budget for the people that invests in housing, education, healthcare, and addressing the climate crisis, not a budget that benefits billionaires like the President. The American people deserve better.          Stay Updated with the Office of Representative Ilhan Omar   Please do not respond to this e-mail. Contact the Office    SUBSCRIBE SERVICES  Unsubscribe  |  Privacy

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                    February 14, 2020               Home About Me Contact Media Center Services                     Passing Bill Increasing the Number of Agricultural Specialists for U.S. Customs and Border Protection  This week, I voted in favor of the Protecting America’s Food and Agriculture Act, legislation I proudly cosponsored. This bill authorizes U.S. Customs and Border Protection to add 240 new U.S. Customs and Border Protection Agriculture Specialists, 20 agriculture canine teams, and additional support staff in the Office of Field Operations each fiscal year. This is expected to continue until the number of specialists sustains the requirements put forward by the Agriculture Resource Allocation Model. It is in the best interest of our national security to ensure that our food supply is sufficiently protected from any outside interference. In my many visits to our Northern Border, I have witnessed firsthand the need for more staffers who are specifically trained in this area. I proudly voted in favor of this legislation to provide adequate resources and staffing at our borders and protect our country’s food and agriculture interests. Read more here,   Urging FDA Action on Dairy Labeling Rules  This week, I sent a letter to the new Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Commissioner Steven Hahn, urging him to take action to enforce the FDA standards of identity that are already in place for dairy products. The FDA has formal rules surrounding the definition of labeling genuine dairy products and alternatives that they have chosen not to enforce for several years. I am also cosponsor of the Dairy PRIDE Act, a House bill that would amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to prohibit the sale of any food that uses the market name of a dairy product but does not come from an animal, and does not contain milk as a primary ingredient. This letter to the FDA is the next step in urging them to act on dairy labeling issues. For far too long, the FDA has failed to combat the misuse of dairy terms on non-dairy products. Not only does this cause confusion among consumers, but it also puts our North Country dairy farmers at a disadvantage in the grocery store. Real dairy products come from real cows, and they should be the only products labeled as “milk”. I will continue to be an outspoken advocate and urge FDA to enforce existing law. Read more here.   Dropping the Puck in Glens Falls to Stick It to Cancer and Helping Kids Learn to Skate   This past weekend, I had the pleasure of attending the community "Try Hockey for Free" event in Glens Falls, where I helped introduce many young constituents to the sport of hockey. This great event was hosted by the New York Rangers hockey team.  I also had the opportunity to participate in the puck drop at the Adirondack Thunder game. NY-21 is hockey country, and it is amazing to see our youth carry on the tradition!  Meeting with Constituents and Groups Important to the North Country    I met with the Agriculture Retailers Association to discuss their priorities, including agriculture labor reform, infrastructure, rural broadband, and the importance of training the next generation of our workforce.    It was great to meet with constituents and representatives from the Center for Lyme Action to discuss the important work they are doing. In Congress, I work diligently to promote prevention and treatment for Lyme disease. I am a cosponsor of the TICK Act, legislation to establish an office of oversight and coordination for tick-borne diseases. I will continue to support increased funding for research into this disease that affects many of my constituents and many people throughout the country.   I also met with General Joseph M. Martin, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army. We discussed many issues facing Fort Drum, including improvements to childcare facilities and childcare facility worker hiring standards. I look forward to prioritizing the Army's requests for the upcoming National Defense Authorization Act. I am proud to be the number one advocate for Fort Drum in Congress. Cosponsoring the Forest Recovery Act  This week, I cosponsored the bipartisan Forest Recovery Act, legislation that will support timber farmers who have been affected by catastrophic loss events. The bill will help forest landowners recover from natural disasters by eliminating the basis limitation rule and allowing them to deduct up to the fair market value of their devastated trees. This levels the playing field for timber farmers who have been impacted by events like extreme weather and forest fires. Farmers across many sectors continue to be impacted by extreme weather events, and not all of them are protected by crop insurance. This bipartisan bill will help timber producers continue their business, which will have a positive impact on many of our North Country communities who include timber production as part of their economic base. Read more here.  Cosponsoring Bill to Ensure All Active Duty Overseas Military Ballots Are Counted  I also became a cosponsor of the Counting All Military Votes Act, legislation to make Express Mail Labels available to deployed active duty military serving on our embassies, consulates, and/or in diplomatic posts. This will ensure each of their absentee votes will be successfully delivered on time by Express Mail in order to be counted. As the Representative of the 10th Mountain Division, the most deployed unit in the U.S. Army, our district understands that their participation in the electoral process is critical. Our brave men and women serving in active duty overseas assignments deserve a say in our government and elected leaders. Each of their votes must be counted, and this legislation ensures expedited mailing for their absentee ballots. We are forever indebted to those who sacrifice daily while fighting for our freedom and I’m honored to advocate for our great servicemembers in Congress. Read more here.  Announcing Housing Development Funding for Glens Falls and Watertown  I was thrilled to announce United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) funding for Glens Falls and Watertown. The Community Planning and Development Program Formula Allocations provide grants to states and local units of government to develop viable urban communities by providing decent housing and a suitable living environment, and by expanding economic opportunities, specifically for low- and moderate-income communities.  Glens Falls will receive $490,696 in funding and the City of Watertown will receive $920,779 in Community Development Block (CDBG) Grants, which will be used to support housing initiatives in both towns. Affordable housing is a prominent issue in many areas in my district, and initiatives like this help communities to provide more affordable and suitable opportunities. I will continue to advocate for programs that enable our local communities to support those in need of assistance. Read more here.   Writing an Op-Ed Commemorating the 40th Anniversary of the Miracle on Ice   This week, I wrote an op-ed commemorating the 40th anniversary of the iconic Miracle on Ice and celebrating the North Country’s rich Olympic history. The op-ed was published in The Sun this week. Read it here.  As always, thank you for subscribing to my weekly updates!    Sincerely,    Elise StefanikMember of Congress             Social Media Corner:       ___________________  Featured Read:   Times Union: State, federal lawmakers clash over access to DMV records      U.S. Rep. Elise Stefanik, R-Schuylerville, a staunch opponent of the Green Light Law, criticized Democrats for "absolutely [leaving] out federal agencies" as they decided to bar immigration officials from accessing DMV databases. Stefanik, whose district abuts the Canadian border, argued that federal officials must access DMV records to check license plates and stop possible criminals from crossing international lines – though she did not draw a connection explicitly between a lack of access to DMV databases and applications for travel perks.  "New York state should repeal the Green Light Law," Stefanik, who is an enrollee in the Global Entry program, said in an interview Monday afternoon. "They should stop prioritizing illegal immigrants over law-abiding citizens."                   _______________  Constituent Services  Please contact my Glens Falls office at (518) 743-0964 if you would like help with:   Federal agencies. Purchasing U.S. flags. Military Academy Nominations. Tours and tickets for your visit to Washington, D.C. Internships. And other resources.  Glens Falls Office  5 Warren Street, Suite 4  Glens Falls, NY 12801  _________________  Weekly Legislative Recap  Below find a list of legislation that the House of Representatives voted on this week. He is cutting $1.6 Trillion from YOUR Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid programs. Not only does his budget contradict his statements at last Tuesday’s State of the Union, it backtracks on promises he has made over and over again. Instead of using his budget to fund critical programs that are working for Floridians, like you, President Trump is:   Cutting Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security: President Trump has broken his promises to seniors and families by slashing half a trillion dollars from Medicare, taking $900 billion from the lifeline of Medicaid, and cutting Social Security Disability Insurance.  Hurting students: The Trump Budget cuts federal student loan initiatives by $170 billion, eliminates the Public Service Loan Forgiveness initiative, and harms children in Central Florida’s public schools by cutting billions from the Department of Education. Abandoning farmers and hungry families: While Central Florida farmers are declaring bankruptcy at record rates, the Trump Budget slashes nearly $60 billion from the farmer safety net and steals more than $180 billion in nutrition assistance from families struggling to keep food on the table. Just in Central Florida, there are over 200,000 residents using SNAP to put food on the table that otherwise they would not be able to do. Cutting investments in jobs and the future of our communities: The Trump Budget breaks last year’s bipartisan budget agreement by slashing a total of $1.6 trillion dollars in the health, education, safety and global security of Central Floridians. Contributing to the national debt by extending the GOP Tax Scam for the rich.   Make no mistake – I will continue to work with House Democrats to stand firm against the President’s broken promises and keep fighting for ALL Americans. If you haven't already, please Like my Facebook page and Follow me on Twitter for the latest updates on my work. Feel free to reach out to my offices in Central Florida or Washington, D.C. to voice your concerns or for help with federal issues.   In Community,Darren SotoMember of Congress                     Washington, DC 1507 Longworth House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-9889Fax: (202) 225-9742 Haines City 620 E Main StreetHaines City, FL 33844(202) 600-0843 | (202) 615-1308Open Wednesday 9AM-5PM Kissimmee 804 Bryan StreetKissimmee, FL 34741Phone: (407) 452-1171 Lake Wales 201 West Central AvenueLake Wales, FL 33853(202) 600-0843 | (202) 615-1308Open Monday and Tuesday 9AM-5PM  Veteran's Affairs Office Lake Nona VA Medical Center13800 Veterans WayAcross the Patriot's BrewOrlando, FL 32827Phone: (202) 322-4476Open 8AM - 4PMEvery 2nd and 4th Friday of the Month Winter Haven 451 3rd St. NWWinter Haven, FL 33881(202) 600-0843 | (202) 615-1308Open Tuesday, Thursday and Friday 9AM - 5PM*Veteran's Hours Wednesdays 9AM - 5PM          Contact Me | Unsubscribe | Privacy

Ordinarily this would begin the annual process of reconciling the administration's budget with that of Congress. However, House Democrats failed to even propose a budget last year. They refuse to propose a budget and begin the process of negotiating how the federal government should allocate its resources because their socialist agenda would make everything – from health care, to college, and more – government-provided, devastating the nation.  Also, the Ways and Means Committee held a mark-up this week on bipartisan legislation to address the issue of surprise medical billing. Continuing reading to learn more about this important piece of legislation.     Addressing Surprise Medical Billing The Ways and Means Committee held a markup on a bipartisan piece of legislation dealing with surprise medical billing. I would like to thank Chairman Neal (D-MA) and Ranking Member Brady (R-TX) for their dedicated work on this thoughtful piece of legislation that protects patients and brings providers, insurers, and hospitals to the table to share in the responsibility of fixing this issue. As a practicing dentist, I can’t emphasize enough that we need to have a balanced approach to expand provider networks, not shrink them. Our bill makes sure that patients come first, but is also fair to both provides and payers in determining a solution. While no solution is perfect, I believe out framework is the best approach to the issue of surprised medical bills and a step in the right direction.   Telephone Town Hall Thank you to everyone who participated in my telephone town-hall last night. A special thank you to special guest Senator David Perdue for taking the time to join the call. We had a large turnout for the event and I appreciate all of the questions that came in. We answered thirteen questions over the course of the call. The questions ranged from impeachment to rural broadband to concealed carry reciprocity – and many others. If you didn't get a chance to ask a question, please click here to leave a comment on my website.  During our call, I asked participants: "A majority of House Democrats are co-sponsors of legislation (H.R. 1384) eliminating virtually all public and private health insurance and replacing with a new government plan, and we’ve heard a lot of talk about “Medicare for All” from the Democrat candidates for President. Do you support this policy which is now the prevailing position of Congressional Democrats/Presidential candidates?" In response to this survey, 88% said they do not support "Medicare for All", while 12% of Third District respondents answered that they did. I also asked: "President Trump recently announced “Phase One” of the China trade agreement along with signing the United States-Mexico-Canada trade agreement. As he looks to pursue free trade agreements with the U.K., EU, and Kenya, do you support the President’s trade agenda? " In response to this survey, 90% of Third District respondents answered they do support the President's trade agenda, while 10% answered that they did not. Thank you again for joining my tele-town hall.    Week in Photos  This week I joined Republican leadership at the weekly press conference.   Click the video below to watch my full remarks.                   It was great to meet with representatives from the Special Olympics. I enjoyed learning more about the educational benefits of the Special Olympics Healthy Athletes program which helps millions of people worldwide.     Thank you to the National Federation of the Blind for stopping by my office this week. We had a productive conversation about the work they’re doing to promote education, economic opportunity, and civil rights for individuals who are blind.  January Jobs Report Another strong job report for January as 225,000 jobs were added, wages increased 3.1% from a year earlier and the unemployment rate is 3.6%. This report shows that the President's economic policies are continuing to benefit all Americans. Click here to read more about the report.           Staying Informed on Coronavirus My office has received several phone calls looking for coronavirus updates. Below is the link to the CDC website for those wanting more information.  Center for Disease Control and Prevention Website   Congressional Summer Internship Interested in spending part of your summer in Washington, D.C. interning on Capitol Hill? My office is accepting applications for the Summer 2020 internship program. The deadline is March 31, 2020. Click here for more information or to fill out an application.   White House Easter Egg Roll This year, the Easter Egg Roll will take place Monday, April 13, 2020, on the South Lawn of the White House. Families with children 13 years old and younger are invited to join the President, First Lady, White House staff, and their families for a day of festivities.   Online Ticket Lottery White House Easter Egg Roll tickets are free to the public and can be requested through an online lottery opening Tuesday, February 18, 2020 at 10:00 a.m. EST, and closing on Monday, February 24, 2020 at 10:00 a.m. EST.  Entering the lottery is free of charge, and winners will be notified via email no later than Wednesday, March 4, 2020. Tickets are not for sale or resale. Those interested in attending should ENTER LOTTERY HERE. It comes as no surprise that the proposed budget is devoid of compassion and empathy, and proposes massive cuts to education programs, housing programs, and critical social safety net programs like Medicare and Medicaid.  Budgets are statements of our values, and I’m committed to ensuring that the Fiscal Year (FY) 2021 federal budget affirms equity and justice for all across our district and our country. Now that the FY 2021 Budget proposal has been released, Congress will begin its appropriations work to develop funding bills that reflect the values of the people.  What is the appropriations process?       To determine how federal dollars get spent, Congress conducts an appropriations process every year. The appropriations process determines how much federal funding goes to government agencies and programs - everything from our schools, to our hospitals, to major infrastructure projects.  Too often, though, the appropriations process takes place behind closed doors. Decisions about how to spend valuable resources are made with little to no input from our communities. Those days are over. Last year, hundreds of advocates and constituents engaged with our office on appropriations priorities, ensuring that those closest to the pain are closest to the power - driving and performing policy making.    How can I be involved?        The appropriations process for FY 2021 is officially underway, and I am seeking your partnership as I work to advocate for the federal resources and programs that serve our communities across the Massachusetts 7th Congressional District.   If you or your organization would like to advocate for a certain federal program, you can submit an appropriations request through this form. The deadline for submissions is Friday, February 28th at 5:00pm EST.  Last year, we were able to secure millions of dollars for federal programs that support community based violence prevention, school based health centers and healthy food options in schools and other critical youth programs.      I’m grateful for your partnership and I look forward to working together to ensure that our federal budget reflects the values we espouse in the Massachusetts 7th. Together, we can secure robust federal resources critical to addressing the issues of consequence for communities across our district and the across the nation. I am committed to being a strong advocate for my constituents, working to improve lives by proposing impactful legislative initiatives, prioritizing constituent services and expanding opportunities. This newsletter serves to provide you with up-to-date information on Congressional work in our district and on Capitol Hill.  From the courtroom to Congress, I have always fought for equality and opportunity; and I am grateful for the opportunity to serve you in Congress to continue that fight.         Sincerely,      “If there is no struggle, there is no progress.” —Frederick Douglass        Greensboro Four Resolution       On January 28, 2020, Congressman G. K. Butterfield (NC-01) and Congresswoman Alma Adams (NC-12) introduced a resolution recognizing the significance of the Greensboro Four Sit-In of 1960. The resolution recognizes the four students for their contribution to the Civil Rights Movement and encourages all States to include this historical account in their educational curriculum. Read the press release and full resolution here.  Background:    The Greensboro Four sit-in protest took place on February 1, 1960. The Greensboro sit-in was a civil rights protest that commenced when four young Black students staged a sit-in at the segregated lunch counter of F.W. Woolworth Department Store in Greensboro, North Carolina. The Greensboro Four: Jabreel Khazan (Ezell Blair Jr.), David Richmond, Franklin McCain and Joseph McNeil were students from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College, now known as North Carolina A&T State University. Nationwide participation in this new movement included over 700,000 people, including students, clergymen and unified citizens both White and Black. On July 26, 1960, the Woolworth Lunch Counter was finally integrated.          CBC Leadership Summit              On February 4, 2020, the Congressional Black Caucus hosted the 2020 National Black Leadership Summit. Over 600 Black leaders from around the country joined the Congressional Black Caucus in Washington, D.C. to call national attention to two critical issues facing the Black community: the 2020 Census and Voting Rights.  Both have implications for the development of Black communities in the short and long term.  The Summit also featured one of North Carolina's own, Rev. Dr. William Barber II, who delivered the keynote address.  Recording of the February 4, 2020 Summit can be viewed on the Congressional Black Caucus' Facebook page here.           Fighting for Medicaid Protections            On February 6, 2020, Congressman Butterfield spoke on the House floor in opposition to the Trump Administration's illegal Medicaid block grant scheme which would threaten access to healthcare for millions of North Carolinians including vulnerable children and those who are low income, elderly, and disabled. The House of Representatives passed a resolution to disapprove of the Trump administration’s latest plan to allow states to convert part of their Medicaid programs into block grants. See Butterfield's full speech here.         Legislative Update        On January 30, 2020, Congressman G. K. Butterfield (NC-01) and Congressman Billy Long (MO-07) introduced the Protecting Natural Gas Consumers from Overcharges Act of 2020.  The bipartisan bill aims to protect natural gas consumers, residential and industrial, from overpaying for their use of natural gas.  The bill amends the National Gas Act to give the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) the authority to set a refund effective date and order a refund when an interstate pipeline is found to be overcharging for its services.  FERC currently has these authorities under the Federal Power Act to order refunds from interstate electric utilities when they determine overcharges have been made. On January 28, 2020, Congressman G. K. Butterfield (NC-01) and Congresswoman Alma Adams (NC-12) introduced a resolution recognizing the significance of the Greensboro Four Sit-In of 1960. The resolution recognizes the four students for their contribution to the Civil Rights Movement and encourages all States to include this historical account in their educational curriculum.  On January 27, 2020, Congressman G. K. Butterfield (NC-1) and Congressmen Mike Conaway (TX-11) introduced H. Res. 810, a resolution to recognize Free File, a public-private partnership allowing low- and moderate-income taxpayers to use tax preparation software and e-filing services at no cost to the government.     Constituent Success Story             The district office in Durham received a request for help from a 95-year-old widow of a WWII Veteran for assistance with the Department of Veterans Affairs. For many years, this constituent had not received her benefits and the Durham office staff was determined to find a solution. After extensive research, many emails, calls and conversations, the district staff was able to identify the error and secured a back payment of  $14,323 as well as a $979 a month pension for the rest of the constituent's life. The constituent and her family expressed deep gratitude for the help of the Durham staff. It is an honor to serve as advocates for the constituents of North Carolina's First Congressional District. We are here for you!                                 SHARE WITH A FRIEND | SHARE ON TWITTER | SHARE ON FACEBOOK   |         /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} }

The President’s State of the Union address detailed the incredible accomplishments America has achieved in the last year. Our middle class is booming and the unemployment rate is as low as it’s been in half a century. Seven million jobs have been created under his leadership, and in Missouri, real median household income is up eight percent. The economy continues to grow, lifting up working families and creating greater opportunities for the next generation. President Trump has said he would get to work for America, and he told us all how he has kept that promise. He has made it a priority to lower prescription drug costs, secure our border, and combat human trafficking. I will continue to work with him for our suburban families to advance critical initiatives such as passing paid parental leave legislation, addressing the skyrocketing costs of childcare, and ensuring our national security remains strong. Now that President Trump has been acquitted of both articles of impeachment, it is time Congress got back to the People’s business of governing and build on his record of achievements for the American people. Read my State of the Union press release here. I introduced bipartisan legislation with my colleagues to help prevent repeated community flooding. We must help regions at risk of repeat flooding become more resilient. By incentivizing communities to plan ahead for damaging floods, we can avoid continually subsidizing the rebuilding of flood-prone properties through the National Flood Insurance Program. This bill aims to prevent loss of life and property and help communities withstand major floods like those we have recently experienced in Missouri. Read more about the bill here. Republicans introduced a privileged resolution to admonish the Speaker for ripping up the President’s State of the Union address. Her action was a slap in the face to the President, the dignity of the House, and all of the Americans the President honored in his speech. Democrats should allow us to vote on this legislation so they can go on record and tell the country whether they support such behavior or not.   I had the honor of singing in the National Prayer Breakfast Congressional Choir with my colleagues. This is such a moving event, and I was blessed to attend.   It was great speaking to the Association of Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialists (ACAMS) to discuss our work in Congress against human trafficking. Financial institutions are critical partners in the fight against trafficking, and I look forward to working with banks, non-profits, and law enforcement as we find new ways to identify traffickers and help victims find justice. I was honored to receive an award from ACAMS for my work in the fight against trafficking and appreciate their support and partnership.   The purpose of U.S. global health and economic development programming is to recognize, promote, and protect the dignity of all individuals, and to extend a helping hand so that the marginalized, poor, and vulnerable around the world may build a better future. Abortion is not compatible with this mission. Children and families should not be enumerated as barriers to prosperity, but seen as sources of strength, beauty, purpose, meaning, and potential. We will not make the challenge of ending poverty a “little simpler” in the short term by pushing women to end the lives of their children. Instead, we will continue to ensure that all women and children have access to healthcare, opportunity, and success. During our Foreign Affairs hearing on women and global health, I asked our witnesses how we can better help women have both their baby and their dreams. We also discussed how abortion is a key driver of gendercide, the global epidemic of violence against women and girls.    I had a great visit with kids from Step Up St. Louis and the Jefferson County Drug Prevention Coalition to talk about the many ways they are working to educate students on the many dangers of addiction and how they can identify the signs.    Sincerely,   Ann WagnerMember of Congress                                        Washington, DC Office2350 Rayburn House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: 202-225-1621    Ballwin District Office301 Sovereign CourtSuite 201Ballwin, MO 63011Phone: 636-779-5449               Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window Click here to open a plain text version of this email If you no longer want to receive these emails, please click here to unsubscribe.  Please DO NOT reply to this email. Our country is stronger today than it has been in years - our economy, our military, our families, our environment, and our communities are stronger. This is thanks in large part to three years of an administration that has made it a point to get government off the backs of hardworking Americans and put America first. Americans across the county are experiencing a "blue-collar boom." We have historically low unemployment, and more Americans are working today than ever before. Industries like construction, healthcare are adding jobs at a robust pace.   Labor participation and wages are rising, especially for the bottom 10 percent of earners. More than 2.5 million Americans have risen out of poverty. In Florida, 630,000 more jobs have been created. Florida homeownership is up 3 percentage points. Real, per-capita income is up 7 percent since the President’s election.  From appointing judges who know and respect the U.S. Constitution; to improving the VA and veteran services; to reducing tax burdens on small business owners and taxpayers; to streamlining and removing unnecessary red-tape that blocked infrastructure investments; to improving our trade agreements for American workers, manufacturers and builders; securing our borders; to and rebuilding our military – President Trump has kept his promises. The President also spoke of the bipartisan success that has been achieved in Washington when Democrats quit playing politics and come to the negotiating table. Under President Trump's administration, including USMCA and a phase One trade deal with China. Another bipartisan achievement is the "First Step Act," which allows inmates serving for drug-related crimes to receive a second chance. I hope my colleagues – Democrat and Republican alike – will put aside politics and work together to invest in our country’s infrastructure, improve border security and reduce and prioritize spending. President Trump’s address also included compelling stories of Americans coming from all walks of life. These guests’ lives illustrate his inspiring message that "Our spirit is still young; the sun is still rising; God's grace is still shining; and my fellow Americans, the best is yet to come!"            (Video of Guests)  _______________  On Friday, the Department of Labor released the January jobs report. Employers added 225,000 jobs in the first month of 2020.  Perhaps more importantly, wages have increased 3.1% from last year.  This report smashes expectations and continues to show that policies reducing regulations and lowering taxes is getting people across the country back into the workforce. The U.S. economy is positioned to fuel more economic growth this year.            ______________ President Trump's message to terrorists has been clear, "You will never escape American justice. If you attack our citizens, you forfeit your life." On Thursday, our military conducted a counterterrorism operation in Yemen that successfully killed Qasim al-Rimi, founder and leader of al-Qa'ida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and deputy to al-Qa'ida top leader, Ayman al-Zawahiri. al-Rimi joined the terrorist group in the 1990s and worked for Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan. Under al-Rimi, AQAP committed countless attacks against civilians in Yemen and sought to conduct and inspire attacks against the United States. His death damages AQAP and the al-Qa'ida regime and brings the U.S. closer to eliminating the threats these terror groups pose to our national security.  _______________  Each year, the U.S. Congress hosts the Congressional Art Competition. This unique competition allows me to showcase the artistic talents of high school students within the 11th District.  The winning entries from each district are prominently displayed in the Cannon Tunnel to the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. The competition is open to high school students only, including home educated students. Each student may enter one piece of artwork that illustrates this year’s theme, the "Wonders of Florida."  For guidelines, deadlines and more specific information, please visit my website.    (2019 Congressional Art Competition Winner)  _______________  Cindy Brown from my local office recently attended The Villages Giving Clubs Showcase. The purpose of this event is to showcase the many clubs, organizations, and groups that work to give back to our community, our region, and the world at large. At least 36 clubs participated. One of the clubs was Angel Snugs from the Villages. Jen Smith and Bonnie Mulneix - leaders of The Villages Angel Snugs club, showcased their mission to teach volunteers to knit, crochet and loom hats. These items are then shipped to 80 pediatric hospitals around the country to help comfort children that have lost their hair due to chemotherapy cancer treatments.     _______________  Last week, my District Director Christa Pearson participated in the First Annual Hernando Grown Student Conference. She spoke to Hernando County high school students about their next steps in achieving their educational and career goals after high school. Thank you and congratulations to all involved in a great inaugural event!     Your servant,     Daniel WebsterMember of Congress    Constituent Corner A member of the Florida Army National Guard stated that he never received the reenlistment signing bonus he had agreed to when renewing his contract in February 2019.  Our office inquired into the situation and learned that a recent backlog had been cleared and that the payment was scheduled to be applied to his retirement fund.  Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you.   District Update Pam Jones from my local office attended the American Heart Association “Wear Red for Heart Health” along with UF Health Leesburg Hospital. “Wear Red for Heart Health” is the American Heart Association’s yearly campaign to raise awareness for women to act against their number 1 killer – heart disease. Dr. Michelle Wood, who is an obstetrician–gynecologist in Leesburg was the guest speaker and shared tips on heart health for women.    Legislative Update Last week the House passed H.R. 2382, the USPS Fairness Act. This bill repeals a mandate from the 2006 passage of the Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act, which required the USPS to fully pre-fund future retiree health care benefits. This requirement is unique to the USPS and has financially crippled the postal service.  By removing this mandate, the USPS has the flexibility to use revenues to improve services and compete while still funding retirement benefits in a sustainable manner. I am a strong supporter of the USPS and a co-sponsor of this bill. This legislation now moves onto the U.S. Senate for consideration.      Results of  which asked...
